Help us make our house our home. We can, and will, ensure that Casa Xalteva will forever remain dedicated to what we do and who we are.    

We have been using the space at Casa Xalteva for 21 years.  It has become our home, but we now stand to lose this building if we do not make it legally ours. 

We need your help to get us as near as possible to be able to purchase Casa Xalteva's building from the original owner.  As a means to raise these funds, we are offering our services as a language school to you in return for your generosity and, regardless of the outcome, you will be able to redeem your perk.

• Two healthy meals every day
• Full tuition scholarships to the best schools and universities available
• All learning materials and uniforms
• Daily tutoring, English lessons and vocational training
• Support for their families.
• A safe place to engage in sports, games and recreational activities

column2: >The level of risk faced by young people in Nicaragua is disproportionately high. Some of the biggest threats facing our youth include: dropping out of school, joining a gang, domestic violence, teenage pregnancy, human trafficking or life on the streets.
column3: > These situations are just around the corner for far too many children here in Nicaragua.

column2: >For 21  years Casa Xalteva Education and Cultural Center has benefited from its landmark location in the center of the community it has been supporting. This building was originally bought by and still belongs to our founder, Ken Carpenter.  We have been privileged to have been able to continue using the space, but in order to ensure that the ""chavalos/as"" can always call Casa Xalteva home, we now need to raise the funds to purchase and register it as part of the Casa Xalteva Foundation.

column2: >We want to be able to continue our operations at Casa Xalteva and keep our doors open to more and more kids in the future.   By purchasing the building we will be able to do that.  Casa Xalteva will have its own permanent location, which will be part of our legally registered Foundation.    This will allow us to continue our work for Nicaragua's underserved youth, and grow and develop into the future.  Right now, we are at risk of losing our home.

column1: <div><span style=""font-size: 30px
<div>
<span style=""font-size: 30px
We are asking for $100,000.   If we meet this goal we will be able to make a major downpayment for the building and transfer the deed in the name of Casa Xalteva.

The building will cost us more than what we are asking for, so if we manage to go beyond our goal, that will also make a huge difference.  However, we are confident that the continuous growth in operations will allow us to successfully make future payments of the property.

<h2><span style=""background-color: initial
<div>

This campaign is all about the Casa Xalteva family, our ""chavalos/as"", staff and people who have visited us from all over the world.   
Here are some of the heroes in this story:
<div>
1. Dayana Rosales, 9 years old.  Member of our Primary School Program
Why did you come to Casa Xalteva?

I started to participate in the program one and a half years ago because my brothers had already been here for a number of years. My mom works all day so it is hard for her to have enough time to look after me. I started to come to Casa Xalteva because my brothers would tell me great things about what they were doing and learning.  After a while I found the courage to ask if I could join. Ever since I have had a second family.
<b style=""font-size: 16px
column4: >What have you learned by being at Casa Xalteva?

column1: Loving and sharing with other people.  Casa Xalteva has also helped me with my homework and this has enabled me to get better grades at school.
What is your favourite memory of your time here at Casa Xalteva?

We took a trip all together in 2015 to place called El Flor de Pochote.  It was an amazing day with all the staff, kids and students together, in which we had time to swim, play, explore and be together as family.
In three words what does Casa Xalteva mean to you?
Structure,
2. Andres Martinez, Casa Xalteva Tour Guide
How did you get started at Casa Xalteva?

I first came to Casa Xalteva when I was nine years old, I was one of the first children to join the program.  A friend of mine who was already here told me what Casa Xalteva offered and how it could help me turn my life around.  I knew right away it was somewhere I wanted to be.  Ken and Gregory gave me the opportunity to be here and that moment changed my life in so many ways.  Casa Xalteva was my home for eight years and it is now my place of work.  If it wasn’t for the chance I had to join the program here, I probably would still be out living on the street.
What has been your most remarkable experience at Casa Xalteva?

It's something which most people would consider pretty ordinary. When I first entered the program, we would all have lunch together, the founders, staff and other children.  Those memories are so special to me.  Before I came to Casa Xalteva there was never any food in my house, so just being able to have lunch every day was amazing. Then there was the feeling of eating and being part of a family,  where we were all laughing and sharing stories together. This was so important to me. It is something that still happens in Casa Xalteva every day, and why this place is so very special to all of us.
How would you describe your Casa Xalteva in three words?
3. Jensen Matus, 12 years old.  Member of our Secondary School Program
Who helped you to join Casa Xalteva?

I joined Casa Xalteva in 2012.  My Mom works and my Dad is not around.  It was really tough for her to provide the things my sister and I needed to be able to go to school, eat and everything else.  She found out about Casa Xalteva  and after speaking with the staff and teachers, I was offered the opportunity to join the program.
How have you personally developed by being at Casa Xalteva?

In the four years I have been at Casa Xalteva, I think I have become a better person.  In addition to all the support provided by Casa Xalteva, such as the food, school materials, scholarships and tutoring, they provide classes and workshops about behavior, team-work, cooperation and other areas-- this really helped me develop on a personal level.
What are the three most important things you receive at Casa Xalteva?
Teaching,
3.  Karla Osejo, Spanish Instructor
When did you start at Casa Xalteva?

When I was 12 years old!  The Founders, Ken and Greg, used to stay at the guesthouse where my Mom worked.  They liked her cooking so much that when they set up Casa Xalteva in 1995, they asked her to cook the lunches for the kids.  So Casa Xalteva became my second home ever since I was a teen.  In the year 2000 I became a Spanish teacher and have been working here since.
How has your time at Casa Xalteva changed you?

Through Casa Xalteva I have grown both personally and professionally.  As a person I have learned to share with other people and appreciate the company of my colleagues and friends in this very special place.  As a teacher I have worked with wonderful students from so many different countries, and have learned new ways of teaching. I'm trying to become better every single day.
What was your happiest moment at Casa Xalteva?

My happiest moment was when my sister, Olma, got married here at Casa Xalteva.  It was a wonderful occasion in which my entire family, along with Ken and Gregory, came to share in a time of utter joy.  Casa Xalteva is such an important place to me and it will always be somewhere that reminds me of this happiness.
What are the three most important things that represent your time here?
Family,
5. Judene Roblero Garcia, 15 years old.  Member of our Secondary School Program
In what ways have you developed personally while being at Casa Xalteva?
Casa Xalteva has given me the opportunity to focus on my education, has supported me with my school work and helped me get the best grades possible throughout primary and secondary school .

My time here has also helped me understand the values of good citizenship. Sharing and working alongside others and people from different cultures has helped me so much.  At Casa Xalteva we work to create a community environment based on love and respect and I adore being part of that.
Which day at Casa Xalteva do you especially remember?

In November 2013 we celebrated a massive milestone for Casa Xalteva, our 18th Anniversary and I will always remember this very special day.  During the morning we had a wonderful celebration with all of the kids, students, staff and volunteers present.  We played games, sang songs and generally had so much fun being all together.  We then all had lunch together and had time to share and reflect on the importance of coming so far as an organization.
How would you describe the meaning of Casa Xalteva to you in three words?
Family,

column5: >If you are able to make a contribution to this campaign, no matter how big or small, your support will help make a huge difference.  By sharing this campaign with your friends and family you will also be helping us to spread this message worldwide.

You can also follow us on Facebook, Instagram, Youtube and Twitter.

Thank You!  

Thank you so much for visiting our page and learning more about the campaign, #OurHomeCasaXalteva. We are truly grateful for your support.  The perks we are able to offer donors are just a token of our appreciation.

column1: On behalf of all the team, staff, children and the entire Casa Xalteva Family,
Thank you for making this possible!
","Our Home - Casa Xalteva

Help us make our house our home. We can, and will, ensure that Casa Xalteva will forever remain dedicated to what we do and who we are.    We have been using the space at Casa Xalteva for 21 years.  It has become our home, but we now stand to lose this building if we do not make it legally ours. We need your help to get us as near as possible to be able to purchase Casa Xalteva's building from the original owner.  As a means to raise these funds, we are offering our services as a language school to you in return for your generosity and, regardless of the outcome, you will be able to redeem your perk. So.... Who Are We?
We are Casa Xalteva. Founded in  1995, we aim to provide at-risk young people with the tools to break away from cycles of poverty and violence.
And What Do We Do?
For each child at Casa Xalteva, we provide...
Two healthy meals every day
Full tuition scholarships to the best schools and universities available
All learning materials and uniforms
Daily tutoring, English lessons and vocational training
Support for their families.
A safe place to engage in sports, games and recreational activities
Love, respect and friendship
And Why Do We Need To Do This?

The level of risk faced by young people in Nicaragua is disproportionately high. Some of the biggest threats facing our youth include: dropping out of school, joining a gang, domestic violence, teenage pregnancy, human trafficking or life on the streets.  These situations are just around the corner for far too many children here in Nicaragua.
Our work is to ensure that as many children as possible are able to escape that cycle and live happy, healthy and successful lives.
Our Business Model

Casa Xalteva is not a charity. We are a non-profit, social business.   This allows us to fulfill our duties to the community in the most sustainable way possible, without being dependent on donations.   The services we provide enable us to generate income, thereby fulfilling our mission to improve the lives of at-risk Nicaraguan youth.
Services we provide:
High quality Spanish language classes
Homestay immersion programs
Life-changing volunteering and internship opportunities
Excursions and cultural activities
Tailor-made programs for schools and groups
As a social business, we operate without outside support, however...
The Next Stage of the Journey for Casa Xalteva
Sometimes we need to ask for help to enable us to do something a bit more than what is normally possible.
This time, we need to ask for your support in a BIG way.

For 21  years Casa Xalteva Education and Cultural Center has benefited from its landmark location in the center of the community it has been supporting. This building was originally bought by and still belongs to our founder, Ken Carpenter.  We have been privileged to have been able to continue using the space, but in order to ensure that the ""chavalos/as"" can always call Casa Xalteva home, we now need to raise the funds to purchase and register it as part of the Casa Xalteva Foundation.

We want to be able to continue our operations at Casa Xalteva and keep our doors open to more and more kids in the future.   By purchasing the building we will be able to do that.  Casa Xalteva will have its own permanent location, which will be part of our legally registered Foundation.    This will allow us to continue our work for Nicaragua's underserved youth, and grow and develop into the future.  Right now, we are at risk of losing our home.
How will this work?
We are asking for $100,000.   If we meet this goal we will be able to make a major downpayment for the building and transfer the deed in the name of Casa Xalteva.

The building will cost us more than what we are asking for, so if we manage to go beyond our goal, that will also make a huge difference.  However, we are confident that the continuous growth in operations will allow us to successfully make future payments of the property.
How Will We Get There?
With your help!
Sharing this campaign on all forms of social media
Telling your friends and family about us
Emailing people the indiegogo link
Promote #OurHomeCasaXalteva
Organize a fundraiser in your local community
Run the marathon for Casa Xalteva?
..... Donate....  (And get free classes!)

When I was 12 years old!  The Founders, Ken and Greg, used to stay at the guesthouse where my Mom worked.  They liked her cooking so much that when they set up Casa Xalteva in 1995, they asked her to cook the lunches for the kids.  So Casa Xalteva became my second home ever since I was a teen.  In the year 2000 I became a Spanish teacher and have been working here since.

In what ways have you developed personally while being at Casa Xalteva?
Casa Xalteva has given me the opportunity to focus on my education, has supported me with my school work and helped me get the best grades possible throughout primary and secondary school .

My time here has also helped me understand the values of good citizenship. Sharing and working alongside others and people from different cultures has helped me so much.  At Casa Xalteva we work to create a community environment based on love and respect and I adore being part of that.

In November 2013 we celebrated a massive milestone for Casa Xalteva, our 18th Anniversary and I will always remember this very special day.  During the morning we had a wonderful celebration with all of the kids, students, staff and volunteers present.  We played games, sang songs and generally had so much fun being all together.  We then all had lunch together and had time to share and reflect on the importance of coming so far as an organization.

Family, Happiness, Achievement
How You Can Help

If you are able to make a contribution to this campaign, no matter how big or small, your support will help make a huge difference.  By sharing this campaign with your friends and family you will also be helping us to spread this message worldwide.
For more information
To find out more about Casa Xalteva you can check out some of the videos and photos on this page.
You can also follow us on Facebook, Instagram, Youtube and Twitter.
If you would like more details about the campaign, please write to us at ourhome@casaxalteva.org

Thank You!  Thank you so much for visiting our page and learning more about the campaign, #OurHomeCasaXalteva. We are truly grateful for your support.  The perks we are able to offer donors are just a token of our appreciation.
Thank you for being part of our family and for making our dreams a reality.
On behalf of all the team, staff, children and the entire Casa Xalteva Family,

column7: >. One of the most important things I've learned during my nearly 15 years as an English teacher is that communication (the ability to speak read and write successfully) is pivotal to the success of the individual
column13: >the community. After years of seeing people struggle because of lack of proper English language and literacy training, I started American English Language &amp
column14:
Learning Center, Inc. so I could better reach out to the multitudes that need English Acquisition and Literacy services. The recently arrived, escaping atrocities in faraway lands, parents of my students who chronically struggle with illiteracy issues, people who know what they need, but have no means of affording it...like ""The Daily Planet"" says, there are so many in need. 

What We Need &

column1: <div>

column4: >Trying to fund a nonprofit can be daunting at best and harrowing at worst. I quickly found this out. You can't charge the astronomical
column5: > rates of for-profit entities (fees that would easily cover your costs),
column9: >. It really is enough to make you scream. I started the program by instructing participants at their places of residence. Our participant base has grown to the degree that we are now in dire need of more professional and practical instructional quarters. We've mapped out a plan to train between 100 and 125 participants (at least 20-25 per five week period) over the next
column21: >months).With this growth, we'll be able to expand our outreach (by 30-50 additional participants) in the following six months. To make this a success, we require adequate financial backing. We negotiate, bargain and shop clearance to keep our expenses at a minimum. These expenses include, but are not limited to the following:

column1: <ul>
• Instructional space/work space (including insurance) at a local community center-$5000.00.
• Instructional supplies, materials, technology, marketing, incidental-$3150.00.
• Instructors, Instructional planning-$9600.00.
• We appreciate your generosity and thus we recognize each of our donors.  We think our Perks are terrific. They allow us to let everyone know how generous you are. Perks include:
• Personalized Electronic Thank You cards for donations of $5.00.
• Personalized Shout-Outs! on our website for donations of $10.00
• Personalized Shout-Outs! on our Twitter/Facebook pages for donations of $25.00 (Individuals).

<li>Corporate Logo recognition and Shout-Outs! on our Twitter and Facebook pages for donations of $250.00 (Corporations).                                                          <span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Since nonprofit funding is an ongoing project, even if we don't meet the deadline, the funds we receive will still be applied toward our six month goal and classes will continue to be in session!

column1: The Impact

column5: >Based on government reports, the numbers of emigrants and refugees migrating to the area are experiencing an explosive up-rise. column1: Risks &

Although most times this is not true, I admit that sometimes I feel like I'm desperately hanging on by myself-against all odds. The biggest obstacle we face is lack of funding. It prevents our reaching out to exponentially more recipients during each session. They still need to learn what we teach, but they have to wait until we can get to them. Proper funding would enable us to reach more participants in shorter time-frames thereby  helping us to make a more substantial dent in a situation that is only getting more intense. Whereas there are other services like ours, the often cost-prohibitive terms, lengthy waiting lists/red tape, and or constantly increasing numbers of new arrivals, support the need for additional comprehensive programs such as ours. We have years of experience successfully teaching reading, writing, and speaking English. Our fundraising efforts are ongoing. In additions to campaigns such as this, we are reaching out to corporate sponsors as well. The obstacles don't stop us, they only make us more resourceful.

Other Ways You Can Help

We welcome any help we can get. Additional ways that are pivotal to our success: 

  • All donations are tax deductible.

• Please, please alert your Facebook friends and Twitter followers, co-workers, etc. to our program.
  • We have a somewhat lengthy Wish-List on Amazon. Any items we receive from our Amazon Wish-List will be adjusted out of the expense budget.

• And please, use your Indiegogo share tools!

    • Thank you,

    Yasmeen Muhammad,
column10:
Learning Center, Inc.  


","Short Summary

column1: I'm Yasmeen Muhammad. One of the most important things I've learned during my nearly 15 years as an English teacher is that communication (the ability to speak read and write successfully) is pivotal to the success of the individual and the community. After years of seeing people struggle because of lack of proper English language and literacy training, I started American English Language & Learning Center, Inc. so I could better reach out to the multitudes that need English Acquisition and Literacy services. The recently arrived, escaping atrocities in faraway lands, parents of my students who chronically struggle with illiteracy issues, people who know what they need, but have no means of affording it...like ""The Daily Planet"" says, there are so many in need.    What We Need & What You Get

Trying to fund a nonprofit can be daunting at best and harrowing at worst. I quickly found this out. You can't charge the astronomical rates of for-profit entities (fees that would easily cover your costs), yet you still have expenses. It really is enough to make you scream. I started the program by instructing participants at their places of residence. Our participant base has grown to the degree that we are now in dire need of more professional and practical instructional quarters. We've mapped out a plan to train between 100 and 125 participants (at least 20-25 per five week period) over the next 25 weeks (roughly 6 months).With this growth, we'll be able to expand our outreach (by 30-50 additional participants) in the following six months. To make this a success, we require adequate financial backing. We negotiate, bargain and shop clearance to keep our expenses at a minimum. These expenses include, but are not limited to the following:
Instructional space/work space (including insurance) at a local community center-$5000.00.
Instructional supplies, materials, technology, marketing, incidental-$3150.00.
Instructors, Instructional planning-$9600.00.
We appreciate your generosity and thus we recognize each of our donors.  We think our Perks are terrific. They allow us to let everyone know how generous you are. Perks include:
Personalized Electronic Thank You cards for donations of $5.00.
Personalized Shout-Outs! on our website for donations of $10.00
Personalized Shout-Outs! on our Twitter/Facebook pages for donations of $25.00 (Individuals).

Corporate Logo recognition and Shout-Outs! on our Twitter and Facebook pages for donations of $250.00 (Corporations).                                                          Since nonprofit funding is an ongoing project, even if we don't meet the deadline, the funds we receive will still be applied toward our six month goal and classes will continue to be in session!
The Impact

Based on government reports, the numbers of emigrants and refugees migrating to the area are experiencing an explosive up-rise. The numbers of those with low-level literacy are also increasing. The reality is helping those in need also helps the community at large. The necessity becomes more profound when we realize that we have interactions with those in need daily and that their deficiencies in the language can and frequently do lead to negative repercussions for immediate community, state, etc. Think--public safety, public health, excessive drain on public assistance programs due to high unemployment,  etc. With your help, our program can do much in the efforts to alleviate these social predicaments.
Risks & Challenges

Although most times this is not true, I admit that sometimes I feel like I'm desperately hanging on by myself-against all odds. The biggest obstacle we face is lack of funding. It prevents our reaching out to exponentially more recipients during each session. They still need to learn what we teach, but they have to wait until we can get to them. Proper funding would enable us to reach more participants in shorter time-frames thereby  helping us to make a more substantial dent in a situation that is only getting more intense. Whereas there are other services like ours, the often cost-prohibitive terms, lengthy waiting lists/red tape, and or constantly increasing numbers of new arrivals, support the need for additional comprehensive programs such as ours. We have years of experience successfully teaching reading, writing, and speaking English. Our fundraising efforts are ongoing. In additions to campaigns such as this, we are reaching out to corporate sponsors as well. The obstacles don't stop us, they only make us more resourceful.   Other Ways You Can Help
We welcome any help we can get. Additional ways that are pivotal to our success:   All donations are tax deductible.

Please, please alert your Facebook friends and Twitter followers, co-workers, etc. to our program. We have a somewhat lengthy Wish-List on Amazon. Any items we receive from our Amazon Wish-List will be adjusted out of the expense budget.
And please, use your Indiegogo share tools!   Thank you,Yasmeen Muhammad, DirectorAmerican English Language & Learning Center, Inc.",7.0,0,"1 Campaign

About forty years ago, our father, Panna Lal Bansal, donated the land his home in

Jamon village to build a school in memory of his mother, Champa Devi Bansal. Despite the fact that Panna Lal ji worked as a government employee, and did not have enough money himself and his 12 children, he built a
school for the Jamon children. Panna Lal ji strongly valued education for his own children and the children of Jamon and understood that it was the only way to a better life. His vision was to
educate and inspire people in the village and help them move to a better
life.
We, at Tulsi Das Charity Organization, would like to continue our
father 's mission and assist with construction and repairs of the
school,  and create a learning program for adults.
keeping the school open but lacks the funds to do so. Currently this school educates more than 172

students at a junior high school level. Once these  students finish junior high school most of them attend a high school a few miles away. Many of these students finish high school and go to college. This junior high school has led to an overall awareness of the importance of education in Jamon. As a result of Panna Lal's work, many of the students have got higher paying jobs and the lives of families in the village have improved greatly.

However, given the lack of resources, the junior high school building needs many basic repairs. If these repairs are not done, the conditions at the school will put the children at risk of injury due to an imminent roof collapse and other structural problems. These repairs are too expensive for the villagers to afford, which is why we are bringing this campaign forward. The founders have been trying to get help from government but but were unable to due to rampant corruption in India.  We are tackling this problem using two approaches -- fighting the government for additional aid and seeking help from kind strangers.

In addition to repairing the school, we would like to establish a learning program for adults so that they can run small businesses, produce and sell handicrafts, and buy/sell inventory. We want to help these adults supplement the income they earn from the laborious farm work. We hope you support our campaign to improve the lives of children and families in Jamon.

Please see our website,

Was ist Svisa Espero?
Svisa Espero ist eine im Frühjahr 2015 lancierte
Halbjahreszeitschrift für Nachhaltigkeit und Sprachpolitik. Sie wird von der
Firma Allsprachendienst Esperanto GmbH in Zusammenarbeit und im Auftrag der
Schweizerischen Esperanto-Gesellschaft herausgegeben und vertrieben. Die
Artikel erscheinen jeweils in einer der drei Schweizer Amtssprachen Deutsch,
Französisch oder Italienisch immer mit einer Übersetzung in Esperanto. Svisa
Espero berichtet über Themen wie Sprachpolitik, Umweltschutz und Energiewende und stellt Projekte, Utopien und Zukunftsvisionen vor. Die Zeitschrift setzt sich einerseits für echte
Mehrsprachigkeit ein und kämpft andererseits gegen sprachliche Diskriminierung

und für die sprachliche Vielfalt. Gleichzeitig soll Svisa Espero einer weltweiten Leserschaft wenig bekannte Gegenden und Teile der Schweiz vorstellen und für einen sanften und ökoverträglichen Tourismus werben und der Welt die Vorzüge des direktdemokratischen politischen Systems der Schweiz aufzeigen und dieses auch als Modell und Vorbild zur Lösung zahlreicher regionaler und globaler Probleme anpreisen. Svisa Espero wird in einer
Auflage von 5000 Exemplaren an Schweizer Politiker und Entscheidungsträger
sowie an die Mitglieder der Schweizer Esperanto-Gesellschaft versandt und kann
einen Monat nach Erscheinen der Printausgabe weltweit als PDF im Internet gelesen und runtergeladen
werden.
Wenn Du noch nie von Esperanto gehört hast: Esperanto ist
die von Ludoviko Lazaro Zamenhof 1887 publizierte Internationale Sprache und
soll dereinst als Zweitsprache aller Menschen die unmittelbare Kommunikation
zwischen Angehörigen aller Völker und Sprachgruppen ermöglichen, ohne dass
dabei einer dem anderen seine Muttersprache aufdrängt.
Was gibt’s Du uns und was bekommst Du dafür?
Mit Eurer Spende für dieses Projekt unterstützt ihr die
Arbeit der Esperanto-Bewegung für eine gerechtere Welt durch eine nachhaltige
Sprachpolitik, den Kampf gegen sprachliche Diskriminierung und die Nutzung von
Esperanto als Kommunikationsmittel im Kampf um den Erhalt unserer Biosphäre und
für die Überwindung der Gräben zwischen den Völkern.
Für Deine Unterstützung bieten wir Dir je nach Höhe Deiner
Spende ein Abo von Svisa Espero, ein Esperanto Lehr- und oder Wörterbuch sowie Platz
für Anzeigen für Deine Produkte und Visionen in unserer Zeitschrift.
Was bezwecken wir mit dem gesammelten Geld?
Mit dem Erlös aus diesem Fundraising soll das Erscheinen von
Svisa Espero bis Ende 2016 gesichert und der Versand an die Schweizer National-
und Ständeräte sowie die Regierungen und Parlamentarier der Kantone, sowie Exponenten
der Wirtschaft und des öffentlichen Lebens finanziert werden. Sollten wir
das angestrebte Sammelziel nicht erreichen, so werden wir das Projekt dennoch
realisieren bzw. weiterführen, müssen aber gegebenenfalls die angestrebte
Auflage und den die Reichweite der Zeitschrift entsprechend reduzieren. Du
kannst unser Projekt jedoch auch über den Ablauf der Sammelfrist hinaus weiter
unterstützen.
Wie kannst Du Svisa Espero sonst noch unterstützen?
Du kannst Svisa Espero nicht nur mit Geldspenden, sondern
auch durch aktive Mitarbeit unterstützen. Gesucht sind interessante Beiträge
über visionäre Zukunftsprojekte, über sprachliche und ethnische Minderheiten,
sprachliche Vielfalt, Energiepolitik, Umweltschutz in französischer, deutscher
oder italienischer Sprache. Unterstützen kannst Du uns auch durch die
Vermittlung von Inseratenkunden und durch die Weiterverbreitung dieser Unterstützungs-Kampagne.
Insbesondere kannst Du den Link unsere Kampagne bei Indigo auf Deiner
Facebook-Seite und Deiner Homepage publizieren und via E-Mail und Twitter an
Deine Freunde und Bekannten weiterleiten.

Short Summary - Kort Opsummering
Hi, I'm Julia and after volunteering for 7 years and managing the London branch of Nightline for 2 years, I'm ready to start my own in my home country of Denmark. Help me make this dream a reality!

Nightline is a listening support and information hotline run by students for students all through the night. There are Nightlines all over the UK and some in Germany, and now we want one in Denmark. We specialise in students because it's a time of a lot of stress and change, and students are also in the age range (18-25) that's at highest risk of first experiencing a mental health problem or suicide.

column5: >Hej jeg hedder Julia, og efter erfaring som frivillig i 7 år og 2 års arbejde som leder i Nightline i England, erjeg  klar til at starte en Nightline i mit hjemland Danmark. Hjælp mig med at gøre denne drøm til virkelighed!

>Nightline er en rådgivning og information hotline drevet af studerende til studerende gennem natten. Der er Nightlines over hele Storbritannien og nogle i Tyskland, og nu ønsker vi en i Danmark. Vi specialiserer os i studerende, fordi det er en tid med en del stress og forandring, og mange studerende er også i den aldersgruppe (18-25), der er i størst risiko for første oplever et mentalt sundhedsproblem eller selvmord.

For at starte en Nightline i Danmark, har vi brug et kontor, en fuld tid koordinator, en fuld tid assistent, faciliteter til frivillige uddannelse og reklamemateriale. Jeg beregner, at det ville koste om året (i DKK):

Selv hvis vi kun får halvdelen af dette beløb eller mindre, vil det stadig få os i gang og give fonde til et par måneder. Hvis vi ikke bliver fuldt finansieret gennem Indiegogo, vil vi forsøge at få en privat fond til at matche, hvad vi får her.
<div>
What You Get - Hvad Du Får
Well of course you get the warm fuzzy feeling of helping start a new charity, no matter what you donate. If you donate over certain amounts, you'll get even more perks.
Nå du får selvfølgelig den gode følelse af at hjælpe starte en ny NGO, uanset hvad du donerer. Hvis du donerer over visse beløb, får du endnu flere frynsegoder.
The Impact - Indvirkningen

There are over 50,000 students in Denmark, who currently have nobody to turn to at night (even the Danish Lifeline closes at 3am). For just 20 DKK (2.60 EUR) per student, Nightline Danmark would support these students at any hour of the night in any way they want to get in touch.
Nightlines in the UK have made a huge difference already, resulting in fewer students dropping out from their courses, and fewer deaths by suicide in the student community.

Der er godt 50.000 studerende i Danmark, der i øjeblikket har ingen at henvende sig til om natten (selv Livslinen lukker kl 3). For kun 20 kroner (2,60 EUR) fra hvert studerende, ville Nightline Danmark kunne støtte disse studerende på ethvert tidspunkt af natten på en hver måde de ønsker at komme i kontakt.
Nightlines i England har gjort en enorm forskel allerede, hvilket resulterer i færre studerende dropper ud af deres kurser, og færre dødsfald ved selvmord i studerende samfund.
Other Ways You Can Help - Andre Måder at Hjælpe

Everyone can donate - not just students. Even small change can make a big difference. If you can't give money, you can still help! Tell your friends, ask your parents, share this post on facebook or twitter.

Alle kan donere - ikke kun studerende. Selv lille ting kan gøre en stor forskel. Hvis du ikke kan give penge, kan du stadig hjælpe! Fortæl dine venner, så spørg dine forældre, og del denne post på facebook eller twitter.

Hej jeg hedder Julia, og efter erfaring som frivillig i 7 år og 2 års arbejde som leder i Nightline i England, erjeg  klar til at starte en Nightline i mit hjemland Danmark. Hjælp mig med at gøre denne drøm til virkelighed!

Nightline er en rådgivning og information hotline drevet af studerende til studerende gennem natten. Der er Nightlines over hele Storbritannien og nogle i Tyskland, og nu ønsker vi en i Danmark. Vi specialiserer os i studerende, fordi det er en tid med en del stress og forandring, og mange studerende er også i den aldersgruppe (18-25), der er i størst risiko for første oplever et mentalt sundhedsproblem eller selvmord.
What We Need - Hvad Vi Skal Bruge

To start a Nightline in Denmark, we need an office, a full time coordinator, a full time assistant, facilities for  volunteer training, and promotional materials. I calculate that it would cost per year (in DKK):
Salaries for Coordinator and Assistant 640,000 kr
Premises for Training 150,000 kr
Office in Copenhagen 120,000 kr
Promotional Items 40,000 kr
Other Possible Expenses 50,000 kr
TOTAL 1,000,000 kr

Even if we make half this amount or less, it will still get us started and running for a few months. If we don't get fully funded trough Indiegogo, we will try to get a private fund to match whatever we get here.

For at starte en Nightline i Danmark, har vi brug et kontor, en fuld tid koordinator, en fuld tid assistent, faciliteter til frivillige uddannelse og reklamemateriale. Jeg beregner, at det ville koste om året (i DKK):
Løn til koordinator og Assistant 640.000 kr
Lokaler til træning 150.000 kr
Kontor i København 120.000 kr
Reklameartikler 40.000 kr
Andre mulige Udgifter 50.000 kr

Selv hvis vi kun får halvdelen af dette beløb eller mindre, vil det stadig få os i gang og give fonde til et par måneder. Hvis vi ikke bliver fuldt finansieret gennem Indiegogo, vil vi forsøge at få en privat fond til at matche, hvad vi får her.

Nightlines in the UK have made a huge difference already, resulting in fewer students dropping out from their courses, and fewer deaths by suicide in the student community.

Other Ways You Can Help - Andre Måder at Hjælpe

Everyone can donate - not just students. Even small change can make a big difference. If you can't give money, you can still help! Tell your friends, ask your parents, share this post on facebook or twitter.

Alle kan donere - ikke kun studerende. Selv lille ting kan gøre en stor forskel. Hvis du ikke kan give penge, kan du stadig hjælpe! Fortæl dine venner, så spørg dine forældre, og del denne post på facebook eller twitter.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Terra
Prime is the
beginning of free global education, access to employment opportunities, and
worldwide prototype collaboration. It is GenDev’s CGI vitrual world where every
user will begin their day to purchase VR modules for personal entertainment,
shopping, education, employment opportunities, intercultural exploration, and
group business collaboration. Join us at www.EnterTerraPrime.com.
TerraVerse is the virtual reality app
store for developers and content providers to upload their AR/VR apps and experiences
to be downloaded by everyday users on any device.  Whether that be a new
course to further your education, new content for virtual travel (i.e., virtual
London, Hong Kong, New York City, etc.), gaming, shopping, or business
meetings.
The
Human Development Prize will gather teams from around the world
to create, compete, and engage in new business creation and rapid prototye development in Terra Prime. Our
Indiegogo campaign will fund our first Human Development Prize.
Terra
Prime exists
in the cloud and will be fully functional on any device—laptop, desktop,
Xbox, PlayStation, tablet, and phone (and yes it is Oculus and Vive compatible).
While it is VR ready, you do not need to
have a headset or super computer to join our global community!
2016: Initial
Terra Prime beta launch and additional content for end-user purchase.
2016: First
global press conference and demo in virtual reality.
2016: Terra
Prime 1.0 launch, including expanded content, TerraVerse app store,
and the release of GenDev’s VR-ready Game “Zombies vs. Celebrities: in
Vegas.”
2017: Applications
and team registration opens for our first Human Development Prize.
Every
human being deserves access to education and employment opportunities—EVERYONE.
Terra
Prime and the Human Development Prize provide invaluable access to those that
would otherwise have limited or no access to education, employment, business
creation, and exploration.
If you
help us during the launch of Terra Prime, you will be a founding supporter of advanced
free education and basic worldwide employment opportunities.
Our
team's background is in advanced VR technology and gaming, international
development, and adaptive educational technology.  Through
our team, partners, adviser's, and network of developers we have built the
most advanced virtual reality rendering engine which powers our Human Development Platform.
Our
team has worked for Microsoft, Apple, HP, Boeing, Activision, EA
Games and numerous corporations and foundations.  We
have experience in holding competitions and hackathons as well as rolling
out culturally sensitive on-the-ground solutions for international development.
Our
connections with corporations, individuals, foundations, NGOs, embassies, and
government departments allow us to brand and scale our engine and VR app store
to not only be used for entertainment and gaming but more importantly, human
development (free VR education and employment opportunities).

can render 200 million polygons before crashing (largest in video game
history).

10,000 players/users per environment or level meaning early adopters will
become industry leaders in next-gen VR game development.
<li>Attain a 90
frame per second VR refresh rate with 500,000 polygons per viewable area.
<li>We are
working alongside Projects for All, creators of the Hello Hub to
bring solar-powered internet-ready computer kiosks to off-the-grid
villages, at risk areas, and refugee camps.

GenDev is a tech company
focused on global human development. We are about to launch a free
virtual world and app store for VR education, e-commerce, entertainment, and
massive gaming called Terra Prime. Come meet your friends from around the world
to learn, work, travel, play, shop, and catch-up. Learn more at www.gendevcollaborative.com.
WHAT
Terra
Prime is the
beginning of free global education, access to employment opportunities, and
worldwide prototype collaboration. It is GenDev’s CGI vitrual world where every
user will begin their day to purchase VR modules for personal entertainment,
shopping, education, employment opportunities, intercultural exploration, and
group business collaboration. Join us at www.EnterTerraPrime.com.
TerraVerse is the virtual reality app
store for developers and content providers to upload their AR/VR apps and experiences
to be downloaded by everyday users on any device.  Whether that be a new
course to further your education, new content for virtual travel (i.e., virtual
London, Hong Kong, New York City, etc.), gaming, shopping, or business
meetings.

Human Development Prize will gather teams from around the world
to create, compete, and engage in new business creation and rapid prototye development in Terra Prime. Our
Indiegogo campaign will fund our first Human Development Prize.
WHERE

in the cloud and will be fully functional on any device—laptop, desktop,

While it is VR ready, you do not need to

and team registration opens for our first Human Development Prize.

Our
connections with corporations, individuals, foundations, NGOs, embassies, and

Host up to

Cal High Athletics Program
Hello everyone! We have 23 varsity sports, and roughly 1300 athletes. We, as
the athletic staff, want to keep our athletes safety. This comes at a cost. At
California High School we have an amazing facility to help our injured
athlete’s recovery from injury, as well as helping the athletes stay
healthy!
California High School's campus is very spread out which is a challenge for the
athletics staff to keep an easy eye on all athletes. Many days there are
numerous events going on, and when one field needs some medical coverage,
timing is everything. A golf cart will help the athletics staff to arrive with
equipment needed in a timely manner.
Our main need in the Cal High Athletic Program is a golf cart. This would
allow the athletics staff to get from one field to the next, or one complex to
another in a fast and timely manner, with all the supplies that may be needed.
There has been a game where an athlete is down on the field, and the safest way
to remove them from the playing surface is to put them on a cart. These carts
can run from $4,000-6,000 used.
As far as other needs this program may benefit from is never ending. Any
money would be helpful in growing this program with new supplies, new
technology as well as keeping up with the newest research to help the Cal High
athletes return to their sport stronger and healthier than ever!

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div>
In the early 1980’s I was young and in college, so doing
stupid things was somewhat expected. One cold winter day my friend Joe and I
had arranged to meet our “gal pal” Mayra at the subway station at 59th Street
and Columbus Circle in Manhattan at 9:00AM in order to go ice skating at
Rockefeller Center. Skating at Rockefeller Center is something of a rite of
passage for New Yorkers so these plans were not strange or odd. What was odd
was the delusion that Joe and I had in our heads that Mayra would show up on
time. Mayra was notoriously late all the time. As Joe and I waited at the bottom
of the escalator off of the street, but not past the point where we would need
to pay another fair, we got colder and colder. To keep warm, we joked around,
danced in place and did all those silly things that college students were want
to do.
Eventually we began to sing. While neither of us was by any means ready for a
solo at nearby Lincoln Center we were not bad, and what we lacked in talent we
made up for in frozen enthusiasm. We got some stares and then eventually we got
a few listeners. Joe who was always bolder than I put his wool hat on the
ground and burst into “Oh what a Beautiful Morning” From Oklahoma. That got us
a few bucks and when I began to croon away to the show’s theme song, with Joe
High Stepping to the beat, we made even more. By the time Mayra finally emerged
from the depths of the subway, Joe and I were singing “I’m just a girl who
can’t say no” at the top of our lungs and had collected nearly fifty dollars,
which was big money in the 80’s.
We had become street beggars. But not as we later justified to Mayra,
panhandlers. We gave the people something that they wanted in exchange they
freely gave us money. We did not set a price
And now I am once again, at least figuratively,  singing “I’m Just a Girl
who can’t say no” at the top of my lungs, as the crowd funding campaign for
American Made College Fairs launches on Indiegogo
We are not panhandling. There are rewards for the donations, no matter how
minor. I had suggested that I go to the largest donors’ home and sing, but my
partners nixed that idea, my voice has not improved with age. Still the rewards
are fun and interesting: T-shirts from the company, Shirts from your favorite
college, a guest spot on our weekly Blab broadcast, your name in the college
fair program and for our “big shots” a fair named in your honor.
But the rewards go far beyond the material goods and ego boosts that are being
offered. College Fairs, our college fairs, strive to reach students who may
never be given the opportunity to attend college. Never have the chance to meet
with colleges and universities. By donating you give them the opportunity.
A couple of weeks ago, I attended an on-line seminar hosted by my colleague Dan
Norris, during the course of the seminar I “meet”, in that on-line way we meet
now a days, a young lady named Janay Sade. Janay runs a company called
mycollegegenie, (www.mycollegegenie.com)
which helps first generation college students and their families adjust to life
in higher education. As we spoke I mentioned that I had been Director of
Recruitment at Lehman College in the Bronx. She then said she had attended the
High School for American Studies on the campus. Small world. We talked more and
I said that when I left Lehman and was working for a college fair company we
had hosted a college fair for that high school in the Lehman cafeteria. “I
remember that fair” she said. She had attended one of our fairs. Now here she
was helping other young people get ready for college
When you drop some change in our wool cap and make a donation to our college
fair fund. That is  your reward
Your donation will go to change the way college fairs are conducted. Many of us remember being in high school and attending a
college fair. We would march into a gym or conference center and the college
and university representatives would be at tables across the venue, one by one
we would visit each table and fill out the inquiry cards. Then slowly the
boredom would set in and we, the students would simply circle around the room,
like fish in a school.
What may come as a surprise to many of you is that college
fairs have not changed. The same fair you attended in 1980 or 1990 or 2000 is
going on today. American Made College Programs intends to change all that. It
is our goal to take the average college fair and turn it into a firestorm.
For the first time colleges fairs will be linked to social
media and the interactive aspects of the internet. Facebook pages for each fair
will allow students to be in touch with colleges even before the event happens,
live twitter feed from the event will allow our fair staff to direct students
to colleges and universities which meet their interest. Snapchat, Periscope and
live stream from the fairs will grant access to populations previously denied
the ability to attend a college fair
We will launch in Fall of 2016 with three fairs: Harrisburg
PA, Frederick/Hagerstown MD and Allentown PA.

Are there risks? Yes of course while not a crowded market there is competition, though none of them are using the firestorm of social media to expand the product.  Re-writing the story of college fairs to include the disenfranchised will require explanation and conversation with various colleges and universities.

But the rewards  will be great . The reward of opening the doors of
college to someone to whom they may have been closed. Your reward is their
access
Please take a look at our campaign. Please donate. And if you really
want, I can of course come to your house and sing

****Please see our wonderful news and latest updates!****

       ****Only two weeks left and $1,500 to raise, can you help us?****

                            The Silver Bullet Sustainable Tiny Life

Tour*

What is the Silver Bullet Tiny House project?

• National model of affordable, non-toxic, zero waste housing under $20K

• Employs all renewable energy systems, water harvesting, permaculture practices

• Mobile sustainable lifestyle education module that teaches by living example

• An average citizen’s way to reduce their consumption and carbon footprint

Your contributions will help me achieve my dream of helping others by showing them my example and helping them design their own sustainable lifestyle.

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

Here's the detailed breakdown of our campaign need of $10,000.00*

Your dollars go to: 

• Gasoline for the 4,030 mile tour:  $  1,887.00

• RV parking for 22 nights at various locations:  $  1,685.00

• Educational Materials for Free Pop-Up Tours (Printed)  $  214.00

• Cost of Campaign:  Crowdsource Fees, Credit card fees, rewards:  $  1,990.00

• Security GPS Devices, Anti-Sway Bar for Hauling, Locks  $  910.00

• Rental of 15’ box truck for tour (6 separate rentals across country)  $  2,960.00

• Video Camera to Archive Tour  $  354.00

* $10,000 is a lot of money. I have put all my energy, savings, and time into the build of this mobile sustainable education exhibit and want to see my dream of sharing with others succeed. Please see below some of the risk mitigation I have planned.

column1: My mission is to cross the USA with my tiny house to teach, motivate, and
inspire children and adults to make informed economic,
environmental and social choices and live healthier, more sustainable
lifestyles.
I have overcome incredible odds to get where I am today. Five
years ago I was penniless, sick, and without affordable housing.  I had been laid off from a financial position
at the age of 60. I faced financial ruin due to medical bills from several
bouts with cancer and Lyme disease. I was homeless.
Instead of giving up I asked myself a lot of questions. I wondered if I could build an affordable mobile, non-toxic, zero-waste home for under $20,000**? Could I build it myself without
any construction experience? Could I raise all the funds to do it while building? Could I design a lifestyle that would sustain me?
I found a
solution. I sold all my worldly goods, bought an 18’ trailer and built myself a
tiny house on wheels equipped with all renewable energy systems and a small
carbon footprint.
I invested my final savings on two things. The first was education. I attended the executive program in
Sustainability Management from Presidio in San Francisco where I learned about bio-mimicry. The second, I founded TerraBluTeams.org, a 501c3
sustainable education non-profit to begin building the Silver Bullet tiny house to teach
others.
I am no
longer sick or homeless. I am stronger, more creative and capable than ever. I
have written a book about my tiny house journey with detailed pictures of my
design based on bio-mimicry. I have become a motivational speaker capable of taking
my story to classrooms, non-profits, sustainability events and tiny house
enthusiasts.
Today I
am experiencing the pleasure and joy of inspiring others to live more
sustainably. Our
non-profit is a young start-up and I am seeking funds to sponsor my first cross-country
tour. With your contributions I will influence over 60,000 people in the summer

of 2016:

• 15,000+ people will see me at tours and workshops

• 45,000+ people will see me at the 2nd International Tiny House Jamboree in Colorado Springs on August 5-7, where I will be returning to give a Sustainable Lifestyle Design Workshop.
I need your help. Your
contributions will achieve my dream to show others my low-carbon, zero-waste
living example and help them design their own sustainable lifestyle. Please give.

column3: >* To see Deek's full tour of the Silver Bullet Tiny House at 60% completion, go to his RelaxShacks youtube channel, click here! We have added so many new features since then!

column2: >My project is valuable to the world as a model of affordable healthy

column1: ","****Please see our wonderful news and latest updates!****       ****Only two weeks left and $1,500 to raise, can you help us?****                            The Silver Bullet Sustainable Tiny Life

Tour*What is the Silver Bullet Tiny House project?• National model of affordable, non-toxic, zero waste housing under $20K• Employs all renewable energy systems, water harvesting, permaculture practices• Mobile sustainable lifestyle education module that teaches by living example• An average citizen’s way to reduce their consumption and carbon footprintYour contributions will help me achieve my dream of helping others by showing them my example and helping them design their own sustainable lifestyle.What We Need & What You GetHere's the detailed breakdown of our campaign need of $10,000.00*Your dollars go to: • Gasoline for the 4,030 mile tour:  $  1,887.00• RV parking for 22 nights at various locations:  $  1,685.00• Educational Materials for Free Pop-Up Tours (Printed)  $  214.00• Cost of Campaign:  Crowdsource Fees, Credit card fees, rewards:  $  1,990.00• Security GPS Devices, Anti-Sway Bar for Hauling, Locks  $  910.00• Rental of 15’ box truck for tour (6 separate rentals across country)  $  2,960.00• Video Camera to Archive Tour  $  354.00* $10,000 is a lot of money. I have put all my energy, savings, and time into the build of this mobile sustainable education exhibit and want to see my dream of sharing with others succeed. Please see below some of the risk mitigation I have planned.
My mission is to cross the USA with my tiny house to teach, motivate, and
inspire children and adults to make informed economic,
environmental and social choices and live healthier, more sustainable
lifestyles.
I have overcome incredible odds to get where I am today. Five
years ago I was penniless, sick, and without affordable housing.  I had been laid off from a financial position
at the age of 60. I faced financial ruin due to medical bills from several
bouts with cancer and Lyme disease. I was homeless.
Instead of giving up I asked myself a lot of questions. I wondered if I could build an affordable mobile, non-toxic, zero-waste home for under $20,000**? Could I build it myself without
any construction experience? Could I raise all the funds to do it while building? Could I design a lifestyle that would sustain me?
I found a
solution. I sold all my worldly goods, bought an 18’ trailer and built myself a
tiny house on wheels equipped with all renewable energy systems and a small
carbon footprint.
I invested my final savings on two things. The first was education. I attended the executive program in
Sustainability Management from Presidio in San Francisco where I learned about bio-mimicry. The second, I founded TerraBluTeams.org, a 501c3
sustainable education non-profit to begin building the Silver Bullet tiny house to teach
others.
I am no
longer sick or homeless. I am stronger, more creative and capable than ever. I
have written a book about my tiny house journey with detailed pictures of my
design based on bio-mimicry. I have become a motivational speaker capable of taking
my story to classrooms, non-profits, sustainability events and tiny house
enthusiasts.
Today I
am experiencing the pleasure and joy of inspiring others to live more
sustainably. Our
non-profit is a young start-up and I am seeking funds to sponsor my first cross-country
tour. With your contributions I will influence over 60,000 people in the summer

of 2016:• 15,000+ people will see me at tours and workshops• 45,000+ people will see me at the 2nd International Tiny House Jamboree in Colorado Springs on August 5-7, where I will be returning to give a Sustainable Lifestyle Design Workshop.
I need your help. Your
contributions will achieve my dream to show others my low-carbon, zero-waste
living example and help them design their own sustainable lifestyle. Please give.

* To see Deek's full tour of the Silver Bullet Tiny House at 60% completion, go to his RelaxShacks youtube channel, click here! We have added so many new features since then!The Impact of the Silver Bullet Tiny House Tour:
My project is valuable to the world as a model of affordable healthy
housing that meets my particular needs while not impacting the environment.
This is the public opportunity to meet a fellow citizen who accomplished this
in a short time for less than $20,000** using reclaimed, recycled and non-toxic
materials.** That amount includes the value of all sponsored materials, the new trailer, oversight/install by licensed plumber and electrician and a portable solar system.
What has my sustainable
education non-profit TerraBluTeams and the Silver Bullet Tiny House
accomplished so far?
• 52 week sustainability best practices website challenges in 2012 & 2015
• Six
Community Cable shows featuring local sustainability leaders
• Twenty Sustainability Lifestyle Workshops at Earth Day/Tiny House Festivals
• Four Community Getting to Zero Projects & Reclamation Art Shows • Sixteen Net Zero
Silver Bullet Tiny House construction workshops and tours

house sponsors and funders who have already given energy systems, workshop
scholarship support, construction tools and materials for the Silver Bullet.

column3: >Imagine a beautiful, peaceful place for people to focus on their creative projects that benefit and enrich society for everyone.

column1:
The Garden will be a creative, self-sustaining environment in the stunning Andalusian landscape where artists, authors, musicians, scientists, companies, you and anyone else can come and concentrate on their work, become inspired by others and slow down.
A workspace where you accomplish more and still feel as if you are on holiday.

We want The Garden to be a win-win project for all:
With your support we can secure the property enabling us then to build The Garden, supporting people enriching society.
Your win is a voucher for a stay at The Garden that is worth more than what you have given us!
Sunrise at The Garden

column2: >Twelve years ago Dominic's father Martin and his wife Diana bought an absolutely beautiful piece of land in Andalusia, planning to build an educational resort for teachers and students. Now they are returning to England and have to sell this jewel of a property. Thanks to their pioneering work the land has water, electricity and the planning permission which fits our project.
>On this foundation we can build The Garden.
>Supporting our project, they have offered to postpone putting it on the market, giving us the unique opportunity to raise the necessary funds and fulfill our vision.

column1: A fresh start to the day

column3:
>What is special about The Garden?

The Garden will be an ideal work environment for creative projects.
Softly integrated into the landscape, we plan to build comfortable

column1: apartments with spacious

verandas and stunning views, plus a wood workshop, an artist's studio, a seminar room and of course a swimming pool. There is even a small river to swim in!

We imagine a vivid, dynamic community of people that might otherwise never meet,
working on diverse projects from business to arts or science,

inspiring each other, sharing different ways of looking at the world.

A big part of our vision is using the revenue to support people who could otherwise not afford to stay in a place like this. We will offer high reductions for anybody enriching society with their work!
Seminar room, atelier and workshop
Work on your project, meet others and be inspired by their ideas.
Stay in solitude in a private chalet or in the communal house.
Give or take part in courses: Art courses, business courses, woodwork or sculpture courses, yoga, language, writing courses …
Simply come and stay for your holiday or use The Garden for a corporate retreat thus supporting the creative work of others.
<div>
Dominic
<div>
I
learned Spanish and building when I first moved to Andalusia as a
teenager. After moving to Germany at age 18 I became a master carpenter
and ran my own building business for several years.
One of the
greatest experiences of my life has been helping to build and run a
large Buddhist Centre in Hamburg St. Pauli. During that time I also
became a skilled project manager organising Buddhist courses with
several thousand participants and also big parties.
It has always
been one of my goals in life to create spaces for people to come
together, feel good and develop their potential. I believe that giving
meaning to life through thinking of others and intelligently sharing the
goodness we have is the only way humans will manage not to destroy each
other and the planet with them.
Be committed, but don’t take
life too seriously!
Heike
After finishing my education as an assistant tax adviser I decided to
follow my love for languages and literature and studied literary
translation in Düsseldorf. As a translator for Spanish and English, I
have benefited a lot from places just like The Garden and have a good
idea of what it takes to create an inspiring work environment that makes
you feel at home.
For the past ten years, Dominic and I have been
living in a big Buddhist Centre in Hamburg St. Pauli, sharing life with
a great community of people. I was involved in planning and organising
events and felt very lucky to be able to use my accounting and administration skills for something meaningful.
I want to support people dedicated
to creating art and culture. I see how difficult it is becoming to make a
living from it and find time and mental space for creative processes. I

believe we need to slow down and see how rich we already are.
That is
why I want to build The Garden.
Eastern view towards La Uma
The Garden is a 7 ha organic olive orchard situated in the foothills of
the Sierra de las Nieves. The river Turón flows along its southern boundary .

Fresh water comes from our own well, olives, figs, almonds, pomegranates, oranges and lemons from our own trees. Electricity and hot water from solar power. With composted leftovers  and filtered used water we will refertilise and irrigate the land.
The Garden will be sustainable, grow it’s own organic food and produce olive oil and other organic products.
The Garden is surrounded by reforested land and olive groves which cannot
be urbanized. It offers views in almost all directions of
ruined castles, big lakes, mountain scapes, a romantic Spanish village
and along a river valley!
Sustainability in The Garden
The Garden is conveniently situated in the Andalusian mountains only 45 minutes from the city of Málaga, it's international
airport, and the warm waters of the Mediterranean. The authentic and picturesque
Andalusian village of Ardales is only ten minutes by car (about 30 minutes walking distance).
The famous trail El Caminito del Rey is just around the corner, as are
many beautiful places for short or long walks through very diverse
landscapes, gorges and pine forests, along rivers,

and over mountains.

The Garden commands views of the Sierra de las Nieves to the west, the
Sierra de Caparaín to the south, in the east are the big reservoirs and
the mountains around El Chorro, to the north the

historic ruins of Turón Castle.

The Garden is less than an hour’s drive from Ronda, Antequera, Málaga
and the coast, two hours from Sevilla, Córdoba and Granada, and is
therefore a convenient base for day trips. It has good
bus connections with Málaga, Ronda and Sevilla. Both Bobadilla railway

station and Santa Ana (the high-speed train) are half an hour away.



View of Castle Turón
<ul>
• We are currently raising the $ 450.000,- for purchasing the property.
• With anything above $ 150.000,- we can make a downpayment and this pristine piece of paradise will not go on the open market and be lost to investors.
• Then we will organise a loan for the building phase, either with a bank or a project friendly investor.

• The more we raise with your help through crowdfunding the less we need to take on as a loan, enabling us to faster accomplish the main goal of The Garden: Offering people benefiting and enriching society affordable accomodation in a special place.
• Starting in  2017, we need three years to build:
<ol>
•  A communal house with 6 en suite rooms

•  Nine apartments, each with an open-plan kitchen and living area and  
     bathroom
•  A seminar room
•  A workshop for arts and crafts
•  An artist's studio
•  A bar/social area
•  A big kitchen for coming together and events
•  A meditation room
•  A workshop for manufacturing organic products like olive oil from the 400 trees
•  A swimming pool
<li> A sauna (yes, it does get cold in winter
•  Do you have any ideas? We would really love to hear them!
<ul>

column3: >Perks: We want YOU to have as much joy and benefit from supporting us as we do!

column1: We have thought up a couple of nice ways to say thank you for your support if you join in on our crowdfunding event. Here are some examples:
Double benefits:
<ul>
<li>For one
you will have the satisfaction of helping to create a place where people enriching
society can slow down, focus on their work, meet and inspire each other.
<ul>
<li>
You will receive

a voucher for a stay at The Garden.
Everybody spends money on holiday accomodation anyway, this time it has a double benefit! And if you can’t come yourself, you are welcome to give somebody else a
beautiful holiday in  Andalusia.

Find out more about The Garden. Visit our home page: www.welcometothegarden.com

column3: >Please share this campaign with your friends, family, colleagues and everyone you know!

column1: Filming the video for Indiegogo

column3: >Epilogue (for people with time on their hands)

column1:
How has the known universe changed after we have accomplished our goal and The Garden is up and running?

 

Ben is a regular guy. He studied economics and joined a consultancy firm after university. Since a teenager, he has wanted to write a science fiction novel, but with school, sports, university, work, etc. he just never got round to it. Ben supported The Garden with 500 $ simply because he thought even if he couldn't, maybe somebody else would find the time to stay there for a while.

He received a voucher for a stay in The Garden. Three years later, after he got a message telling him that the building phase was complete and The Garden was running, he booked a flight to Málaga on a whim, rented a little car, and 45 minutes later arrived in a beautiful resort surrounded by olive groves with views over mountains and castles and a picturesque village, looking down on a small river with pools one can swim in. He checked in and walked in the shadow of trees to his chalet. The gentle rushing of the river traveled through the summer air and caught his attention, calming him on a deeper level. Just for fun he took his computer with the notes for his novel out of his suitcase and put it on the desk in the open living room/kitchen area of his apartment. The room had an amazing view of the countryside, it gave him a feeling of space.

A welcome note on the table informed Ben that The Garden was self-sustaining. Fresh drinking water coming from a well and the electricity from solar power. It felt good to be somewhere at one with nature and not against it. Next to the note was a little bottle of  organic olive oil made from the trees growing on the land as a welcome gift.
After prolonging his stay for two more weeks and finishing the first raw version of his book, Ben returned home feeling totally refreshed and alive.

He told his colleagues about his time there, meeting that jazz musician who'd been composing a piece about his father, and Miriam the painter from Germany who had been staying there for two months, and that he had made so much progress on his book. He told his boss about the possibility of using The Garden for a company retreat, he liked the idea and suggested it to his employees. One year later Ben and 20 of his colleagues landed in Málaga and were picked up by Dominic from The Garden. Spread around the property in their apartments, Ben's colleagues where really glad to have followed his advice. The seminar room was a dream! Wide wooden flooring, the planking cut directly out of a tree trunk, big windows offering a view across the river valley to the forested land opposite. The big veranda in front of the seminar room offered enough space to sit outside in the shade of a canopy. Coming here had been the best idea ever. Without the hustle and distraction of a regular conference hotel and with a deeply satisfying energy of concentration and relaxation at the same time.
The company retreat was so productive that Tom, Bens boss, spontaneously suggested that each year he would sponsor one of his employees to come for a two week retreat to follow their passion.

Toms book never became a bestseller, but it was published and sold a couple of thousand times which was anyway much more than he had ever dreamt of. Miriam the painter visited him later and they still stay in touch. A friend of the jazz musician, a scientist working on his second doctorate who had finished all the research and just needed a good place to write it all up, stayed on at The Garden and later won the Nobel Prize!

The Story behind ...

Twelve years ago Dominic's father Martin and his wife Diana bought an absolutely beautiful piece of land in Andalusia, planning to build an educational resort for teachers and students. Now they are returning to England and have to sell this jewel of a property. Thanks to their pioneering work the land has water, electricity and the planning permission which fits our project.
On this foundation we can build The Garden.
Supporting our project, they have offered to postpone putting it on the market, giving us the unique opportunity to raise the necessary funds and fulfill our vision.

It felt good to be somewhere at one with nature and not against it. Next to the note was a little bottle of  organic olive oil made from the trees growing on the land as a welcome gift.
After prolonging his stay for two more weeks and finishing the first raw version of his book, Ben returned home feeling totally refreshed and alive.

He told his colleagues about his time there, meeting that jazz musician who'd been composing a piece about his father, and Miriam the painter from Germany who had been staying there for two months, and that he had made so much progress on his book. He told his boss about the possibility of using The Garden for a company retreat, he liked the idea and suggested it to his employees. One year later Ben and 20 of his colleagues landed in Málaga and were picked up by Dominic from The Garden. Spread around the property in their apartments, Ben's colleagues where really glad to have followed his advice. The seminar room was a dream! Wide wooden flooring, the planking cut directly out of a tree trunk, big windows offering a view across the river valley to the forested land opposite. The big veranda in front of the seminar room offered enough space to sit outside in the shade of a canopy. Coming here had been the best idea ever. Without the hustle and distraction of a regular conference hotel and with a deeply satisfying energy of concentration and relaxation at the same time.
The company retreat was so productive that Tom, Bens boss, spontaneously suggested that each year he would sponsor one of his employees to come for a two week retreat to follow their passion.

Toms book never became a bestseller, but it was published and sold a couple of thousand times which was anyway much more than he had ever dreamt of. Miriam the painter visited him later and they still stay in touch. A friend of the jazz musician, a scientist working on his second doctorate who had finished all the research and just needed a good place to write it all up, stayed on at The Garden and later won the Nobel Prize!",10.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Hamburg, Germany",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-garden-space-for-development/pica

My Name is Aleena Zahir, a Ugandan female Pan Africanist  ,Singer and  Activist residing in kampala with a strong back ground and experience in tackling the black American Problem.The Idea of the African American Retreat to Africa is my creation supported by Greater African Radio and Tv Africa  Uganda.

My Goal is to help bridge the gap between Africa and African  Americans world wide and to bring minds together for a long and lasting solution to the problem facing the African Americans.As Africa watches from a distance ,many lies are spread out here and as a result Africa is not doing much or enough to help the black person.

The gap that is between us needs to be filled to allow us appeal to our African Governments to have one Strong Voice in asking for Justice ,freedom and Equality for the African American.The War is great that many African Americans are so afraid and ignorant of their fellow African,the Universality of the problem is not understood because we are divided, we easily give excuses to not  fight for our rights,the poverty holds us down like we will never get up.The Image the media gives about the African American on the African Continent paints a bad picture that makes Africans think African Americans are thugs while painting Africans as poor and corrupt, sick and hungry. It is us to help self because no body will. 

I first started interacting with African Americans back in 2011 when I made my first Music album,""Making History"". By Interacting, learning and listening to their stories especially the Police Brutality facing them ,I became convinced to stand for them and especially connect them back home in Africa where they belong.

 

The Money Raised will cover costs of flight, hotel and food for Sister Tamara Jones and Brother Saladin Shabazz- Allah  stay in Africa ,Uganda.

Your Donation will make you a part of the great Fighters who are on the front line for the betterment of the black person world wide.The Late Alfred Olango who was shot and killed in El Cajon, California was Ugandan National. He had to be one of the many African Americans who have died at the hands of American Police  not because he was mistaken for African American but because he has a black Skin. Black People ought to Unite.

 

Please make this a great cause and a campaign worth paying attention to by spreading word as much as you could. 

Ugandan Pan Africans are eagerly waiting to see African American Sisters and Brothers on the Ugandan Soil.If any of you would afford to be here do not hesitate to contact me.If you could  give the little to support the Soldiers representing us.

 

The Retreat will see these attend discussion panel,Radio and Tv Talk shows, Meet Political Leaders and Tour the most exciting Cultural Sites, Mountains of the Moon,Igongo Cultural Center, Owen Falls Dam ,Kasubi Kings Tombs and different national Parks.

If You love to see black people progressing ,Act Today

Thank you so much

May you stay Blessed.
