(Gaius Kowene and Allason Leitz- VERY excited about Yole!Africa in 2014).
Allason-

This campaign is important to me, because in the four trips I've taken to the DRC every summer for the Salaam Kivu International Film Festival, I've seen the importance of organizations that work in their own communities. Yole!Africa and SKIFF in particular hold a place in the heart of this city in a way that inspires participants to not just learn but also to give back by volunteering at the festival. It's truly an organization with an impact.

Every penny you give to this campaign will go into getting more equipment for youth attending the center to tell their stories. I've worked with this organization for four years and have seen how every single penny we get is used in the most effective way possible for the youth. We're not partnered with International NGO's or for that matter with anyone who is going to tell us to put our energy into places that aren't going to serve the youth first and foremost. That's why we need your help today, to contribute, person to person, heart to heart to an organization that has effected the lives of over 23,000 youth annually in a region fraught by constant conflict and war.
Contributing to this Indiegogo is a chance for your
contribution to make both a local and a global impact. On a local level you’re
donation will give youth access to equipment and skills that the youth can
apply to their lives every single day. On a global level, the youth having the
resources to tell their stories will increase a humanist  awareness about the
atrocities taking place in the region.
Some Background and What we're asking for!

Here are some more of the basics about what makes Yole!Africa and SKIFF unique and a great opportunity to be involved in through this Indiegogo! The festival and cultural center have been a cover story in the ART section of the New York Times (2014). We've been written up in Aljazeera (2014) and in the Economist (2010) among many, many other places. Our work hasn't gone unnoticed, and now it's your moment to join the movement.
Brief History of SKIFF:

The Salaam Kivu International Film Festival (SKIFF) was founded in 2005, when the war in the east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo was escalating and the region, as defined by international press outlets, was exclusively a place of violence and despair. To combat both the frustration of the local community and the misrepresentation of the international media, internationally acclaimed filmmaker and activist Petna Ndaliko Katondolo launched SKIFF, the first international film festival in the DRC. Since its inception, SKIFF has been a vehicle for peace, positive socio-political transformation, and has provided the wider world with an increasingly diverse vision of the east of Congo, one that includes exceptional talent, beauty, and joy despite the challenges of the region.

After nearly a decade of steady growth, SKIFF now regularly brings together more than 15,000 people from around the world, who want to participate in a meaningful event that,time and again, confirms the power of art and culture to change the world for the better.

When SKIFF began in 2005, it was the first event of its kind in many ways. Not only was it the first venue that brought a diverse selection of international films and videos to Congo, it was also the first time the local community gathered together with force around their artistic talents. Despite the backdrop of soldiers and tanks moving through the streets as rebel troops advanced within 5 kilometers of the city, even at the first edition of SKIFF thousands of people came together in a non-violent demonstration calling for peace. The collective effect of this gathering was a growing awareness among the community that art is central to the practice of peace. With this knowledge, the community has become increasingly empowered to speak out about social problems and advocate positive solutions.
Brief History of Yole!Africa:

Yole!Africa, founded in 2000 by internationally acclaimed Congolese filmmaker and activist Petna Ndaliko, is a center for creativity and cultural exchange based in Goma, in the east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Yole!Africa is based on the belief that offering local populations – and youth in particular – tools of non-violent self-expression and critical thought will allow them to participate actively in shaping their own realities.

The center’s mission is to promote peace through art and culture as well as to operate as a platform for exchange where young people from different backgrounds and social status can come together to express themselves through their talents.

Yolé!Africa is neither a political nor a denominational organization, through its programs it promotes and encourages value and respect for all human beings (regardless of race, origin, religion, ethnicity or gender), and stands against all forms of exploitation or violation of human rights. As an organization, Yole!Africa seeks to promote and encourage art. It supports artists and offers them a place conducive to creativity. It also links the community and its artists in order to strengthen the common culture and identity. Through trainings, workshops and community events, Yole!Africa promotes dialogue and respect for others and, through debate and reflection on current social and political issues, generates the awareness that everyone is an actor of her/his life and of the society in which she/he lives and has the right and duty to make of it a better place.
WHAT WE'RE ASKING FOR:
We're asking you for $23,252 to buy camera's, tripods, editing equipment (i.e. hardware/software) and a generator.
Here's the breakdown of what it all costs and where the money you contribute is going:
Canon 7D: http://bhpho.to/1d7E00T
SD Cards: $500
Tripod (x4) = $2,316
Manfrotto Fluid Head and Tripod System : http://bhpho.to/1qGrPxc
Editing Equipment (x2) = $5,200  + $2600 = $7,800 TOTAL
Memory: 32GB 1600MHz DDR3 SDRAM - 4X8GB
Storage: 256GB Flash Storage
Software: $2,600
Adobe Creative Suite: http://adobe.ly/1H4UXFr
Generator (x1)= $2,136
Subaru 6500W: http://bit.ly/1JhE4ar
Transportation= $500
GRAND TOTAL: $23,252

While this is the total that we'll need to reach our goal. Obviously, if we don't, we'll use what we have to continue to build on the core elements of our lab. Depending on our total funding, we'll prioritize camera's and editing equipment as those are both essential components for the youth to get started.
Remember what Gaius Kowene says in the video ""SKIFF is a necessity for young people here in the region…
for me [the festival] is an inspiration showing that we can do something great.” Let's work together to make this possible for more youth in the region.
The Challenges

Yole!Africa has an outstanding reputation in the area and is at the heart of the community. Yet In a region where 8 million people have died in the last 25 years poverty and constant displacement are an issue security can at times be an issue. We have had one incident of theft in the past five years, yet we were able to recover majority of the equipment stolen. While theft is always an impending threat, by and large the organization has taken significant steps to prevent a second breach of security on the premises. We taken measures to prevent a recurrence  by heightening our security measures and hiring a guard to stay on the premises at all times. Additionally, the system for renting out equipment is more rigorous and requires more strict identification now than it did before. All of this helps us to control (without hindering youth from access) who is on the premises at all times.   Other Ways You Can Help What are the chances you read all of this and felt so inspired you went to open your wallet only to remember there isn't much green inside? Well not to worry! We are always looking for in-kind donations and all sorts of different contributions.
Are you on social media? CLICK SHARE!!! It's probably one of the best things you can do to help us get the word out about this campaign!
Are you a professional artist interested in teaching a class at the center?

column2: > Since 2007, DUFP has worked with street children in the Arts Centre community, teaching drumming, dancing and drum-building and offering tutoring services. Now, DUFP is embarking on a new project in Senya Baraku, a fishing and farming community on Ghana's coast where children and families live in deep poverty, often sending their children off to work at very young ages. Our current plan is to bring an arts-based curriculum to schools, churches, orphanages and other places where children gather in Senya Beraku, to teach them English through the lens of poetry, spoken word and rap, and work on their math skills through the lens of drumming and dancing. We hope to engage our own DUFP artisans from the Accra Arts Centre as paid staff in this effort, thereby giving these amazing artists a way to make a living. We plan to utilize our small plot of land in Senya Baraku, where we recently completed the building of a well, as a place for volunteers to stay while we all work to forge relationships in the community through a common language - the Drum. We are planning a tour in January 2016 for volunteers to come and work in the community with us, helping to begin this important programming.  But first - we need to raise money to start our new DC Storefront: ""Hands On Drums.""

column1: ABOUT HANDS ON DRUMS

On June 15, 2015, Kweku Owusu and Kristen Arant (www.drumlady.com, founder of the Young Women's Drumming Empowerment Project) received notice that they had been chosen for a new initiative by Cultural DC called Storefronts DC. This initiative will allow Drumming Up From Poverty to have a storefront for 3 months. We will call our store ""Hands on Drums,"" and it will serve as a
column2: > central location, a studio, and a place to build drums, sell drums, teach people how to play them, and allow the magic of drumming to build community, and incite joy and healing.

column1: • Help covering the cost of shipment.
• A hand-painted sign, lighting, display counters and other items to boost the appearance of Hands on Drums.

The Impact

You are helping us open a Storefront.

This is the biggest opportunity we've ever had for the beautiful work of Drumming Up From Poverty artisans to be showcased. After our 3-month stint, if our store and studio are successful, we may be able to keep the space longterm. Your help on the front end will give ""Hands on Drums"" what it needs to draw people in - beautiful, handmade works of art and incredible drums to touch, play and learn on. And if we are allowed to keep going, that means longterm support for our DUFP artisans in Ghana. It means consistent work for them. It means economic empowerment. And the success of Hands on Drums ensures the success of DUFP
column2: it means lasting relationships building between Americans and Ghanaians, united for the cause of inspiring young people through arts-based education, giving them and their families hope for the future.

column2:
Challenges

Our greatest challenge is ensuring word travels fast about Hands on Drums, in order that as many people as possible will visit the store in its 3-month stint, starting in September. The ensured success of the store will lead to sustainability for DUFP.

","ABOUT DRUMMING UP FROM POVERTY
Founded in 2007 by Michael
Kweku Owusu, DUFP works to improve the
quality of life of street children living in the heart of Ghana by
mentoring them in traditional drumming, dancing, and drum making.

By    teaching children drum building, traditional drumming and dancing, they learn valuable   skills that can provide for their futures while they develop a   strong sense of cultural pride and heritage.  Children and youth also develop a   sense of caring and responsibility for each other along with the    confidence that comes from self-expression. Michael Kweku Owusu is the project's founder. He grew up in the Arts Centre - a constructed
community attached to Accra’s Centre for National Culture, where

some of Ghana's most talented artists and craftspeople live and work. Since 2007, DUFP has worked with street children in the Arts Centre community, teaching drumming, dancing and drum-building and offering tutoring services. Now, DUFP is embarking on a new project in Senya Baraku, a fishing and farming community on Ghana's coast where children and families live in deep poverty, often sending their children off to work at very young ages. Our current plan is to bring an arts-based curriculum to schools, churches, orphanages and other places where children gather in Senya Beraku, to teach them English through the lens of poetry, spoken word and rap, and work on their math skills through the lens of drumming and dancing. We hope to engage our own DUFP artisans from the Accra Arts Centre as paid staff in this effort, thereby giving these amazing artists a way to make a living. We plan to utilize our small plot of land in Senya Baraku, where we recently completed the building of a well, as a place for volunteers to stay while we all work to forge relationships in the community through a common language - the Drum. We are planning a tour in January 2016 for volunteers to come and work in the community with us, helping to begin this important programming.  But first - we need to raise money to start our new DC Storefront: ""Hands On Drums.""
ABOUT HANDS ON DRUMS

On June 15, 2015, Kweku Owusu and Kristen Arant (www.drumlady.com, founder of the Young Women's Drumming Empowerment Project) received notice that they had been chosen for a new initiative by Cultural DC called Storefronts DC. This initiative will allow Drumming Up From Poverty to have a storefront for 3 months. We will call our store ""Hands on Drums,"" and it will serve as a central location, a studio, and a place to build drums, sell drums, teach people how to play them, and allow the magic of drumming to build community, and incite joy and healing.
Hands on Drums will Feature the following:
Daily store “open” hours
Hand-carved, artisan drums of all sizes to be displayed, touched, played or bought

This site is in the Galilee region of Israel, just south of Megiddo (where we get the term ""Armageddon""!). OUTREACH:

  • The excavation takes place on land that belongs to Kibbutz Megiddo, and the people who live on the kibbutz are welcome participants in the project. Locals in the region learn about the rich cultural heritage of which they are part. Kibbutz Megiddo supports
column10:
>Furrows, a special needs program that houses and cares for over 100 individuals of all ages who live with a range of conditions. These individuals join the excavation project for part of each day, and the communication between all parties involved cuts across national, cultural and social boundaries.

  • JVRP has teamed up with Moshav Yotfat in the Galilee, to provide a dig experience for high school students. Exciting and important cultural exchange happens between the international excavation team and Israeli teenagers.

","Hello!! My name is Gabby and I am a graduate student at the Harvard Divinity SchooI, where I study Hebrew Bible and Jewish studies. I have been accepted to volunteer as part of an international team for the Jezreel Valley Regional Project this summer!! I have never been on a dig before, and would learn a tremendous amount, but I need some help to get there and back, and for room and board, if I plan to carry on with my studies once I come home...! What is the PROJECT? For their 2015 season, JVRP will be excavating in Legio - the site where the 6th Roman legion was stationed in the 1st and 2nd centuries CE, during a VERY important time in Jewish, Christian, and Roman history. This site is in the Galilee region of Israel, just south of Megiddo (where we get the term ""Armageddon""!). Besides being committed to learning about the past, this team is a model of how academic study can be a starting point for community building. Below are some details about the outreach the team does, and the historical significance of the site: --> OUTREACH: The excavation takes place on land that belongs to Kibbutz Megiddo, and the people who live on the kibbutz are welcome participants in the project. Locals in the region learn about the rich cultural heritage of which they are part. Kibbutz Megiddo supports Furrows, a special needs program that houses and cares for over 100 individuals of all ages who live with a range of conditions. These individuals join the excavation project for part of each day, and the communication between all parties involved cuts across national, cultural and social boundaries.JVRP has teamed up with Moshav Yotfat in the Galilee, to provide a dig experience for high school students. Exciting and important cultural exchange happens between the international excavation team and Israeli teenagers.

This is the first archaeological project to have the full cooperation of BOTH Israeli and Palestinian authorities. The long-term goal is to join S.H.A.R.E (The Society for Humanitarian Archaeological Research and Exploration), whose Common Ground Initiative promotes cooperative education, shared cultural heritage, and archaeological research between Israelis and Palestinians. http://archshare.org/SHARE_Website/Home.html.--> HISTORICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE SITE:You can read about the discovery of the site here!This will be THE FIRST Roman military base of this period to be properly excavated in the eastern half of the Roman Empire!!Uncovering the material remains of this Roman legion will help us tap into really important questions: How were the Romans conducting themselves during the aftermath of the Jewish Wars (66 - 70 CE) and the Bar Kokhba Rebellion (132 - 135), when the Jews were expelled from Jerusalem? Why is ECE
important?
Early
childhood education is a branch of education theory which relates to the teaching of young children
(formally and informally) up until the age of about eight.  It has become a prevalent public policy issue
in many places in the world, as municipal, state, and federal lawmakers
consider funding for preschool and pre-k. ECE focus on five developmental
domains of childhood development which include: Physical, emotional, language,
and cognitive skills. But Most of the children in the world who live in slums

do not have access to education due to many reasons.


The
education system there can sometimes be unfair, challenging, and brutal for
children who are not enough prepared to compete
column2: children who are not given the

column1: proper support as well as attention from their parents and families. The main
reasons behind that is political instability, poverty, environmental disaster
and many other reasons that we may not be aware of, regardless of what reasons
there are to it, the result most likely isn't in the favor of the child or the

community.


"" political instability ""
This Picture taken In Gaza-Palestine by Media Town.

"" political instability ""
This Picture taken In Gaza-Palestine by Media Town.
We, as SEED,
a team consisting of college students who are living in a historic conflict
zone called Palestine. Many of the children in here are victims of trauma,
violence, war, blockade, poverty and many unthinkable horrors that children
shouldn't be subject to, which is the case in many other places around the
world like Syria, Yamen, Nigeria, Sudan .. etc. Having access to ECE is
sometimes easy, but healing the scars in the souls of the children can be a
challenge in many of these regions.
the power of change, the youth, the future leaders in those societies and we
want to make a change that we ask you take part of.

Creating a
nongovernmental, nonprofit program with partners from the local community as well

players of our team are college students who are looking to make a change.

college students can have much larger impact on young children than old
housewives running informal day cares, a vast amount of options, skills, and
hobbies can be brought up in children at a young age if they were surrounded
with lively and active environment rather than a traditional education system
that focuses on an early assessment process for children’s ability to memories
and comprehend text books. Arming them with the skills and knowledge might be
enough, but giving the freedom to choose and explore could have a much stronger
impact on the way they go about their daily life at school.
SEED team has its goal set on 15,000, and they can’t do that

We have

the Urban slums can be unpredictable, as well as the vast amount of

","Why is ECE
important?
Early
childhood education is a branch of education theory which relates to the teaching of young children
(formally and informally) up until the age of about eight.  It has become a prevalent public policy issue
in many places in the world, as municipal, state, and federal lawmakers
consider funding for preschool and pre-k. ECE focus on five developmental
domains of childhood development which include: Physical, emotional, language,
and cognitive skills. But Most of the children in the world who live in slums
do not have access to education due to many reasons. The
education system there can sometimes be unfair, challenging, and brutal for
children who are not enough prepared to compete
column2: children who are not given the

column1: proper support as well as attention from their parents and families. The main
reasons behind that is political instability, poverty, environmental disaster
and many other reasons that we may not be aware of, regardless of what reasons
there are to it, the result most likely isn't in the favor of the child or the
community.""  political instability ""This Picture taken In Gaza-Palestine by Media Town.""  political instability ""This Picture taken In Gaza-Palestine by Media Town.
poverty""taken from this site: "" http://yucatanhoy.com/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=4658:la-pobreza-reduce-la-capacidad-mental&Itemid=118 "".
We, as SEED,
a team consisting of college students who are living in a historic conflict
zone called Palestine. Many of the children in here are victims of trauma,
violence, war, blockade, poverty and many unthinkable horrors that children
shouldn't be subject to, which is the case in many other places around the
world like Syria, Yamen, Nigeria, Sudan .. etc. Having access to ECE is
sometimes easy, but healing the scars in the souls of the children can be a
challenge in many of these regions. We represent
the power of change, the youth, the future leaders in those societies and we
want to make a change that we ask you take part of.
Our
objectives:
Enforce holistic, effective and affordable pre-school programs, which
is accessible by everyone.
Involve other children or members of the family where possible – this
could generate important spillovers.
Close the gap in school achievement
that often exists between poor and minority children and their middle-class
friends.
Share the goal of enhancing early learning
and development through cognitively stimulating activities.
Having positive impacts on children’s
cognitive skills and/or school outcomes, with the largest effects reported from
some state pre-K programs.
Why do we care? Why should you
care?
Measures of brain activity show that
during the second half of a child's first year, the prefrontal cortex, the seat
of forethought and logic forms synapses at such a rate, that it consumes twice
as much energy as an adult brain. That furious pace continues for the child's
first decade of life.
During the first month of life, the
number of connections or synapses, dramatically increases from 50 trillion to 1
quadrillion. If an infant's body grew at a comparable rate, his weight would
increase from 8.5 pounds at birth to 170 pounds at one month old.
90% of brain growth happens by age 5.
At cost of 50,000-100,000$ per year
quality childcare is just not affordable and accessible for many parents.
What are we going to do
about it?
Creating a
nongovernmental, nonprofit program with partners from the local community as well
as international partners, and private companies that understand the need for a
safe, stable, developing community.
The star
players of our team are college students who are looking to make a change.
Hence the program will run in partnership with universities that understand the
need to invest in ECE, which in return will increase the number of students
seeking higher education. How can that help solve the problem?
Motivated students with skills and qualifications will
be selected by the university system to take part in the program.
Following the selection process, each student will be
trained by different specialized parties on several levels.
A list of existing local day-cares and informal
kindergartens will be at hand. Based on their skills and place of residence
each student will be provided with a timetable and a list of activities which
he must carry out in one of the day-cares as part of the program.
Each student
will have a profile on our website, where he will be evaluated by the
supervisors, parents, and our partners. Based on this evaluation students will
receive their scholarships, tuition discounts as part of the reward system.
Young
college students can have much larger impact on young children than old
housewives running informal day cares, a vast amount of options, skills, and
hobbies can be brought up in children at a young age if they were surrounded
with lively and active environment rather than a traditional education system
that focuses on an early assessment process for children’s ability to memories
and comprehend text books. Arming them with the skills and knowledge might be
enough, but giving the freedom to choose and explore could have a much stronger
impact on the way they go about their daily life at school.
SEED team has its goal set on 15,000, and they can’t do that
without your help. The $15,000 fund will be used for three purposes:
to renovate 5 places provided either by the government or existing poor
day-cares through
Providing music instruments, sports
equipment “toys” and some electronic devices in order to introduce them to new
technologies.
Provide a safe play space where they
can release all of their energy and stress that result from their daily
struggle.
Buy school supplies for 20 students –
we will start with small underprivileged day-cares and preschool facilities.
Provide staff members –college
students- to help those qualified entrepreneurs run their facilities more
efficiently and manage their investment without neglecting their students.

Short Summary

The Internet is a wonderful tool most of us use in our daily life. Unfortunately for some people, often children, the Internet is a source for continued abuse. There are ways to analyze, detect and report the presence of child abuse material being shared on different platforms and we know how to do it.

In February 2014, we started to map the occurrence on open file sharing networks. The result was shocking. Now, one year later, we can see that it has not decreased but has actually increased. Not by much, but it is an increasing problem.

We are a dedicated team consisting of programmers with more than 30 years of experience between us. The software we have developed is finished and ready to start working. Now we need servers to run it on.

What We Need

This is what we are asking for:

  • $4550 to purchase servers
  • $450 to transport the servers to a data center
  • $550 to have them installed in the data center
This sums up to $5550, or as we would like to see it, 5550 persons donating one dollar each.
If we don't reach 100% funding we will cut down either on servers or service (transport and installation). It depends on where we end up.
Indiegogo's fees will be covered by us personally.
<div>
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
By supporting this campaign, you help to provide us with an advanced set of tools that will greatly increase our effectiveness.

Today we are limited by both collecting and analyzing capacity. If this campaign is successful, we will be able to cover larger areas, collect terabytes of data (that is a lot) and have it analyzed within a couple of hours (maybe even less).
Every positive predator match will then be reported to the police for confirmation and they will take it from there.
We want to be absolutely clear about how we work. We do not download any actual child abuse material, as that would be illegal even for a good cause.
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

We fully understand that there are persons who want to donate to this campaign but cannot. Remember that money is only half of this campaign. Marketing is the other half and helping us with that part is free.

  • Share the link to this campaign
  • Talk about it
Thank you!

86 Years of Serving the Community

We believe that when everyone has access to the resources they need, the world will become a much better place. The Cambridge Community Center helps to make that possible.

CCC has been serving our neighborhood for 86 years. We volunteer our time to the Center because we believe in its mission: promoting cooperation and empowering youth, individuals, and families through year-round community enrichment.

We provide K-8 Out of School Time Programming primarily to underserved populations because regardless of income, race, or inequity, all children deserve high quality programming.
column7: >The Big Picture: Modernizing the Center

column1: <div>
<div>
<div>
With your help, we plan to renovate our 19th
century home to reflect the needs and
uses of our 21st century community. We want to give our neighborhood the accessible community center it deserves.
$25,000 - New and Improved Accessibility Ramp
If we raise half our goal, we will reconstruct the Howard Street handicap access ramp according to the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) standards.
$35,000 - Demo the Old Ramp
With your support, we will demolish the old ramp in the front of our building to allow restoration of basement-level windows, allowing natural light into basement classrooms.
$50,000 - Replace Gym Access
If we meet our goal, we can also replace our gymnasium ramp with a safer ADA-compliant ramp.
$75,000 - Renovate Front Entrance
With your generosity, we will replace our 1960's main entrance with a brand new entry way and energy-efficient doors.

column7: >What We've Done So Far
column13:
>

We have been dedicated to raising money to modernize the Center since 2008, with completed projects including a new playground, fully restored fire escapes, and a new roof on our gymnasium. One of our most recent building improvements was replacing the seventy-year-old windows in the gym last fall. Behold:

Before:

column1: Hosting the 2014 Cambridge Science Festival beneath broken windows.
After:
Hosting the Cambridge Winter Farmer's Market (left) and our annual Senior Thanksgiving Luncheon (right) under the glow of brand new windows.
<div>
<div>

column5: >Over 400 individuals and organizations have already donated to our renovation project in amounts ranging from $1 to $150,000. Funding will be provided in part by your generosity, the Amelia Peabody Charitable Fund, Harvard University, the Cambridge Historical Commission, the Cabot Family Charitable Trust, and the support of our community.

>Your donations are part of an initiative that will ensure that the Center will be around to serve many more generations of Cambridge families. Your generosity contributes directly to the well-being and future of our city!

column1: Mentor for development in Liberia
was founded with a promise to create the next generation of successful and
socially responsible leaders. We believe that today’s youth are the leaders of
tomorrow
column2: therefore, there is a huge  and immediate need to provide them with guidance, skills, resources and

column1: opportunities to fulfil their potential and become positive change agents
within their communities.
What we've done so far

In 2013, we piloted our first peer mentoring project. We recruited, screened and matched ten college students to serve as role models to help ten high school students at-risk of dropping out of school. Mentors met with their mentees once weekly after school to provide listening, guidance and support through: discussion, homework help, test preparation and goal setting activities.

During the Ebola crisis, from November, 2014 to January, 2015, we conducted an emergency home schooling project and reached out to over 200 underprivileged primary aged children with free tutorial classes followed by homework in Mathematics, English, reading, writing and spelling.
We need your help...
To increase our impact, we are seeking to raise
$15,000 to start a Learning Resource Center to provide students in Liberia with
uninterrupted access to knowledge, skills, resources, connections and
opportunities to fulfil their potential and create solutions to lasting
problems within their communities. The center will provide: Library services, homework help, peer-tutoring, mentoring,
computer literacy programs, leadership and entrepreneurship trainings supplemented
by youth to business forums and other networking events to connect youth with
opportunities to gain or create employment and lift their communities out of
poverty. MDL’s Learning Resource Center will be a safe place that will attract
boys and girls off the streets, inspire, equip and engage them to become
empathetic, innovative, resilient and ethical community and global leaders.
Your support will be enable us purchase equipment, supplies and cover operational expenses for three months, which include:
Furniture (i.e. chairs, desks, tables, shelves)
Risks & Challenges

Our budget to operate for six months is $29,500. We cut down to three months and established a new goal of $15,000 because it's our first time crowdfunding. We need your support to meet and exceed this minimum target. Even if we don't exceed target students will still have free access, while the public will pay a fee to be able to sustain the center.
Other Ways You Can Help
We understand your desire to support, but maybe you may not be able to contribute financially at the moment. There are other ways that you can still support us meet our goal:
Create a personal request and forward this page to your friends and family via Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, newsletter and anywhere else.
You may also donate any of the items on our list by emailing us at mentor4developmentinliberia@gmail.com
We're in this together!
Thank you for supporting Liberia's next generation of socially responsible leaders.
Sincerely,
Gerald Hodges",2.0,0,"1 Campaign

Hello! We are
Sarah and Melanie, the founders of Cleveland Tutors. We are asking for your
help to provide high-quality tutoring for low-income students in the Cleveland
metropolitan area through the Cleveland Tutors Scholarship Fund. But first,
we’d like to tell you a bit about who we are and why we’re running this
campaign now.
<div align=""center"">
Sarah and Melanie
both grew up in Shaker Heights, OH, a historic suburb of Cleveland, OH.
However, they didn’t know each other until the summer of 2013 when Sarah moved
back to Cleveland after over 15 years away, including time spent in Colorado,
England, and Germany, while she was completing her MA and Ph.D. in International Relations and
teaching at the university level in her field. After her Ph.D., she worked in
social services in Seattle, WA, but decided to return to teaching in her
hometown. Starting in the fall of 2013, she divided her time among part-time
university teaching in the Cleveland area, substitute teaching for the
Cleveland Heights-University Heights School District, and independent tutoring. Sarah saw there was a huge demand for tutoring, but not everyone could afford it.
<div align=""center"">
At the same time, Melanie was working for the Cleveland Metropolitan School
District in Human Resources supporting principals’, students’, and the central
office’s blend of personnel and technological needs for substitute teachers. As
she had for much of the last 14 years, she found she was happiest when teaching

and training others. As she coached youth ice hockey in Cleveland Heights, she realized that teaching was her passion, especially helping players one on one and in small groups. While she was helping the school district, Melanie also
began taking Master’s level education classes, eventually adding a part-time
job tutoring 5<sup>th</sup>-7<sup>th</sup> grade students in another local
suburb. Melanie recognized that many students needed extra support to get tutoring, but their families didn't have the financial resources to help.
Between Sarah’s extensive teaching and tutoring career and Melanie’s business
and education background, it only made sense for both to be tutors and to work
together to build a tutoring company.
So, in March of
2015 they founded Cleveland Tutors.
<div align=""center"">
There
are lots of companies out there that provide a marketplace to connect tutors

and students. Sarah was working with one of those companies before.
Why start a
new one?
Here are three
important reasons:
1)
Not
all of these competing “tutor-student marketplace” sites verify their tutors’
educational qualifications. Instead, some create their own “certifications” or quizzes
to assess whether someone is qualified to tutor. These arbitrary
“certifications” lead to …
2)
Lack
of transparency and accountability. Who chooses the content of these tests?
What research shows that a quiz is an accurate measurement of subject and
teaching knowledge?<span>  If you take the SAT,
you know that the College Board is behind it. But if you take XYZ Tutoring
Company’s test about geology, how do you know that someone qualified in
assessment and in the field in question wrote it?
3)
Personal
relationships matter. Yes, big tutoring ""marketplaces"" have customer service
staff. But, do they know their tutors and their students personally?
<div align=""center"">
<div align=""center"">
So, Melanie and Sarah personally interview every tutor and verify their
transcripts to make sure every candidate is qualified to tutor. Since different
people want various levels of support finding a tutor, Sarah and Melanie created www.clevelandtutors.com themselves to
help students find a tutor and schedule a meeting in seconds or communicate directly
with them so students can find the right fit with a tutor. Beyond making the
match between tutors and students, they also provide continuing, available support
for the tutor-student relationship. Building relationships this way is also an
important means for them to be able to make a positive contribution to the
community.
<div align=""center"">
Since
March, Melanie and Sarah have done more than build a website. They have been
hard at work networking in the community, designing marketing materials, and,
of course, tutoring. They also brought on two additional tutors, Margaret
Richardson, Ph.D. and T.J. Kohlrust, MA. Now, they could offer tutoring in over 20 subjects. The community’s responses to Cleveland Tutors have been
positive. However, they are still a new company, and becoming known takes time.
From the very beginning, Sarah and Melanie were dedicated to serving the
community. When they think of the community, it means all people, not just
people who can easily afford a tutor’s services.<span>  People who can’t easily pay for a tutor should
have the same access to a tutor that wealthy people do.
In
order to serve the community sooner and more effectively, they decided to run
this campaign for the Cleveland Tutors Scholarship Fund.
<div align=""center"">
Melanie
and Sarah’s combined tutoring, teaching, and coaching experience totals over 12
years. They have guided people from all walks of life, from youth ice hockey
players to graduate and professional students. The diversity among the students
is striking, including various ages, experiences, and income levels. Because
Melanie and Sarah have worked with such a variety of students, they agree
that tutoring is for everyone. Everyone should have the opportunity to work

with a tutor if they need one—regardless of their ability to pay.

We’re running
this campaign so that we can provide free, high-quality tutoring to the
community this summer. For many students, summer is a time when they need
tutoring the most in order to catch up and/or prepare to retake tests they may
not have passed the first time. Tutoring also provides a much needed diversion
for students who may not have many other activities on their schedules.
<div align=""center"">
Here’s the
breakdown:
That’s
50 students who will work towards reading at grade level, who will sharpen
their study skills, and who can start the school year with greater
confidence.
<div align=""center"">
<div align=""center"">
<div align=""left"">Students
at Title I schools (schools where all or the majority of students qualify for
free or reduced lunch) would be automatically eligible to apply for a
scholarship for a block of hours. Scholarships would be for 10 hour blocks,
which would be renewable on the basis of need and the availability of funds.
<div align=""center"">
Several
reasons. The data on Title I schools is readily available. There is consensus
among economists and government agencies that this is an indication of low
income status. Further, it preserves the dignity of the scholarship applicants
and their families by not asking them to reveal details about their personal

financial situation.

Hold on a minute! Why are tutors being paid $40/hour? If a non-profit
were running this campaign, they would be able to serve many more people
because their tutors would be volunteers or paid much less. Well, low
pay is a problem we want to address. How can we raise funds to serve a
population who wouldn't be able to afford to work with a tutor on one
hand, while paying tutors low wages that mean they can't afford to live?
$40/hour is a fair living wage for a self-employed tutor. A tutor
making $40/hour is accepting a mid-range wage for the field (tutoring
rates range from $15-$120/hour, depending on experience, location, and
subject tutored). And remember, a self-employed person pays higher
taxes. Finally, hourly rates acknowledge that a tutor isn't just working
when he or she is with a student
column2: tutors must prepare for each session

column1: and stay up to date on their fields.
For
the sake of fairness, allocating scholarships of 10 hours or less ensures that
as many students as possible get a chance to receive tutoring. If funds are
still available, students may apply to renew their 10 hour scholarships. We
will notify students if this becomes possible.

Now, we've heard people say, ""Cleveland Tutors isn't a non-profit, so I can't give to your scholarship fund."" Here's the thing, though: non-profits pay their employees, too. They don't magically convert 100% of the money they receive into serving the needs of others. They can't. Non-profits have overhead: salaries, utility bills, office space. By contrast, Cleveland Tutors has nothing to pay but the cost of a few materials and postage for some donors' thank you gifts. The rest of the funds go directly to tutors' rates. And since tutoring is the service we're providing to meet the needs of others, that means that nearly all of the funds raised go towards directly serving the population in need. Your donations make it possible for tutors to give their time, energy, and expertise to students who need them.
<div align=""center"">
If
we make less, we won’t be able to provide as many hours of free tutoring. If we
make more, we’ll be able to provide more tutoring time for students who need it.
<div align=""center"">
Then
we’ll bring on more tutors! We already have received more tutoring applicants
than we have been able to bring on.
<div align=""center"">
<div align=""center"">
We
appreciate that you took the time to review our campaign for the Cleveland Tutors Scholarship Fund. We believe in giving
students the chance to get the help they need and that you do, too. You can
help build a sense of community through education from wherever you are. We truly
appreciate your contribution of any size and your kindness in sharing the word about our campaign with friends and family. Please know that your generosity will
make a real difference to the students.
<div align=""center"">

Sources:

","Hello! We are
Sarah and Melanie, the founders of Cleveland Tutors. We are asking for your
help to provide high-quality tutoring for low-income students in the Cleveland
metropolitan area through the Cleveland Tutors Scholarship Fund. But first,
we’d like to tell you a bit about who we are and why we’re running this
campaign now.
Sarah and Melanie
both grew up in Shaker Heights, OH, a historic suburb of Cleveland, OH.
However, they didn’t know each other until the summer of 2013 when Sarah moved
back to Cleveland after over 15 years away, including time spent in Colorado,
England, and Germany, while she was completing her MA and Ph.D. in International Relations and
teaching at the university level in her field. After her Ph.D., she worked in
social services in Seattle, WA, but decided to return to teaching in her
hometown. Starting in the fall of 2013, she divided her time among part-time
university teaching in the Cleveland area, substitute teaching for the
Cleveland Heights-University Heights School District, and independent tutoring. Sarah saw there was a huge demand for tutoring, but not everyone could afford it.
At the same time, Melanie was working for the Cleveland Metropolitan School
District in Human Resources supporting principals’, students’, and the central
office’s blend of personnel and technological needs for substitute teachers. As
she had for much of the last 14 years, she found she was happiest when teaching

and training others. As she coached youth ice hockey in Cleveland Heights, she realized that teaching was her passion, especially helping players one on one and in small groups. While she was helping the school district, Melanie also
began taking Master’s level education classes, eventually adding a part-time
job tutoring 5th-7th grade students in another local
suburb. Melanie recognized that many students needed extra support to get tutoring, but their families didn't have the financial resources to help.
Between Sarah’s extensive teaching and tutoring career and Melanie’s business
and education background, it only made sense for both to be tutors and to work
together to build a tutoring company.
So, in March of
2015 they founded Cleveland Tutors.
There
are lots of companies out there that provide a marketplace to connect tutors
and students. Sarah was working with one of those companies before. Why start a
new one?
Here are three
important reasons:
Not
all of these competing “tutor-student marketplace” sites verify their tutors’
educational qualifications. Instead, some create their own “certifications” or quizzes
to assess whether someone is qualified to tutor. These arbitrary
“certifications” lead to …
Lack
of transparency and accountability. Who chooses the content of these tests?
What research shows that a quiz is an accurate measurement of subject and
teaching knowledge?  If you take the SAT,
you know that the College Board is behind it. But if you take XYZ Tutoring
Company’s test about geology, how do you know that someone qualified in
assessment and in the field in question wrote it?
Personal
relationships matter. Yes, big tutoring ""marketplaces"" have customer service
staff. But, do they know their tutors and their students personally?
So, Melanie and Sarah personally interview every tutor and verify their
transcripts to make sure every candidate is qualified to tutor. Since different
people want various levels of support finding a tutor, Sarah and Melanie created www.clevelandtutors.com themselves to
help students find a tutor and schedule a meeting in seconds or communicate directly
with them so students can find the right fit with a tutor. Beyond making the
match between tutors and students, they also provide continuing, available support
for the tutor-student relationship. Building relationships this way is also an
important means for them to be able to make a positive contribution to the
community.
Since
March, Melanie and Sarah have done more than build a website. They have been
hard at work networking in the community, designing marketing materials, and,
of course, tutoring. They also brought on two additional tutors, Margaret
Richardson, Ph.D. and T.J. Kohlrust, MA. Now, they could offer tutoring in over 20 subjects. The community’s responses to Cleveland Tutors have been
positive. However, they are still a new company, and becoming known takes time.
From the very beginning, Sarah and Melanie were dedicated to serving the
community. When they think of the community, it means all people, not just
people who can easily afford a tutor’s services.  People who can’t easily pay for a tutor should
have the same access to a tutor that wealthy people do.
In
order to serve the community sooner and more effectively, they decided to run
this campaign for the Cleveland Tutors Scholarship Fund.

<div>
We are in our Prototyping stage and research Stage.
HOPE, is an eCommerce platform that will seek to build credibility of people living in in areas below the poverty line who do not get employment easily.

We are on a prototype stage to build this platform which will allow us to educate these students offline in a classroom close to their community, teaching them the both soft skills and hard skills. Post the training we help ""Potential Employers"" connect with them online and conduct interviews with them.

The total project post the prototyping stage is approximately 700,000 USD . We are looking at starting in India and Mozambique Africa. The Prototyping stage will have us build the dummy platform and test the waters before we implement this project. 
Our Vision is to eradicate poverty globally and help elevate the lives of the masses. As founders we have already put in a considerable amount of money in conducting research by flying down to India and understanding the different scenario of the living conditions of people living in these places. 
""I want to become a singer"" a young girl living in the slums told us . She would practice everyday but did not have any means to take this further. As a company we are motivated to take this ahead and help people improve the quality  of their lives.

Inspire Kids to Dream Big, Set Goals, and Persevere

We believe kids have what it takes, and that sometimes all they need to reach their dreams is a champion. Classroom Champions partners with teachers in grades K-8 classrooms to provide inspirational mentor relationships between Olympians and Paralympians, and classrooms at under-served schools. Our amazing teachers facilitate this relationship, engage their students in lessons about subjects like goal-setting, perseverance, community, leadership, and friendship, and support students in giving back to their communities. 

Inspired kids + Inspired teachers + Inspired mentors = Inspired communities.

Want to support American students? Click here.

Classroom Champions was founded in 2009 by Olympic Gold Medalist (now our President &
column2:
CEO) Steve Mesler, and his sister Dr. Leigh Mesler Parise because they believe kids deserve a bright future. Classroom Champions now inspires kids in the US, Canada, and throughout the Caribbean with incredible mentors and committed teachers. We need your help to inspire more kids, and to continue our work of providing social and emotional skills through mentorship to deserving kids. 

Why is Social and Emotional Learning important for kids to grow up successful? Read Steve Mesler's brief Op-Ed here!

What We Need &
column3:
What You Get
  • GOAL: $12,000. This money will ensure support to TWO MORE classrooms of kids in Canada. That's two classrooms in some of our most at-need areas of the country that will receive mentorship from our best athletes for the entire school year. Your donations will support, train, and connect passionate teachers and engage families and communities to help kids learn the skills they need to succeed in school and in life!

  • PERKS for YOU*: To see the awesome benefits you receive for supporting Classroom Champions kids, look over there ------------------>
column4: • WHAT HAPPENS IF CLASSROOM CHAMPIONS DOESN'T MEET OUR GOAL or IF YOU HELP US EXCEED IT? That's an easy one... if we don't reach our goal, your support will help as many kids and teachers as possible. If you help us exceed our goal - MORE KIDS will participate and learn the skills they need to succeed!

column1: We inspire kids to dream big, set goals, and persevere. We believe every child has the right to learn the process of excellence, yet many students in under-served communities face significant barriers to gaining these critical skills. We work hard to partner with teachers to instill qualities of excellence in students that will last the rest of their lives.
Why is Classroom Champions important to kids and schools?

column2: >Classroom Champions is an innovator in social and emotional education across the continent. Our unique method sees thousands of students' lives changed on a yearly basis at a fraction of the cost of traditional programs that see similar results. Social and emotional learning is so important that the renowned Brookings Institute recently said social and emotional development is the next school reform frontier and quoted that:

column1: ""...for every dollar invested in Social and Emotional Learning programs, there is a return of eleven dollars, a rate of economic return that would be the envy even of hedge funds.""

A University of Alberta study highlighted the program of engagement in Canadian schools in 2011. They found that up to 66% of Canadian students are considered disengaged in school. They state that bored, restless, disruptive, and disengaged students in the short term have clearly documented negative impacts on students, teachers, schools, and communities - and that students could be graduating incapable of or unprepared for a productive and healthy life.

Well, 100% of Classroom Champions teachers say being a part of the program INCREASED ENGAGEMENT in their classrooms. If you were engaged, would you be more likely to attend work or school? Would you be better at what you do?

For the past five years Classroom Champions has been partnering with teachers in the schools that need our help the most to change the lives of the kids they teach. Want to see all the other ways Classroom Champions transforms kids, teachers and mentors? Click here for our impact results!
<div>
Our innovative system to inspire students, support teachers, and transform schools:
Get involved! Other Ways You Can Help:

Right now, what we need most are the financial resources to help us make things happen. What can you do? Spread the word, tell the story of why you are involved, and invite others to join you in giving. Share our cause with your workplace. Find out if your employer has a donation matching program. Here are some ideas:
<ul>
• Share Classroom Champions’ campaign with your family, friends, and social networks.
• When you share with family and friends, send a personal email, message, or even a phone call.
• When you share on social media, tag @ClassroomChamps. Here is this fundraiser link to share with your friends and family: http://www.classroomchampions.org/content/755/2015-Indiegogo-Campaign
• We would love to hear your story about someone who inspired you to be the person you are today. Tweet, comment, and/or post on Facebook and we'll share your story too!
Charitable Status + Tax Receipts

column2: >Those of you who have been with us a long time might remember that Back to School Project was the original name of Classroom Champions back when Leigh and I first started it - wow how we've grown! When you make a donation to this campaign, you will receive an official receipt for income tax purposes from Back to School Project Foundation. The Back to School Project Foundation is the registered charity that supports and oversees Classroom Champions programming in Canada.

Why Admiring
Smartphones are capable of doing much more than just making phone calls now, with the capabilities &
column2: convenience they also bring vulnerabilities. Since we <span>often came across sensitive, personal information through various mobile applications, security &amp

column1: Passwords, keys, and fingerprints are the conventional method we use to protect our smartphones. Yet, these can be copied &
column2: reproduced. We need something that is unique &amp
column3: cannot be duplicated to improve the safety level.

FAQ
Q: My skin is allergic to nickel, does the material of Admiring contain
nickel?
A: No, Admiring is made of nickel-free, aircraft grade titanium.
Q: What mobile operating system does Admiring
Application Support?
A: Admiring currently supports Android operating system. A Windows Phone
applications will follow.
Q: What are the requirements on my phone to use
Admiring?
A: The only requirement is that your phone supports NFC. If your phone
does not support NFC, you can still use Admiring for opening the NFC
doors. Our designers will appreciate you for choosing to wear it purely for the
stylish design!
Q: Does Admiring work with iPhone?
A: Because iPhone doesn’t support NFC, so you cannot use it with Admiring.
However, if you still want to use both of them, you can consider buying an NFC
enabled iPhone case.
Q:
If I have lost my Admiring, how do I gain access to my locked apps?
A: The Admiring package box is a backup device, simply tap the box to your
phone to unlock apps. You can also setup a 4-digit access code for your apps.
Q:
Is it hard to change settings for locked apps?
A: Choosing which app to lock is easy, simply pick the app of your choice in
the App Locker list.
Q:
If I have all different colours of Admiring, what to do when I switch wearing a
different Admiring?
A: Our application support multiple Admiring. Beside Admiring, other type of
accessories will follow.
<div>
<span style='color: rgb(106, 106, 106)

Smartphones are capable of doing much more than just making phone calls now, with the capabilities & convenience they also bring vulnerabilities. Since we often came across sensitive, personal information through various mobile applications, security & privacy are extremely important.

Passwords, keys, and fingerprints are the conventional method we use to protect our smartphones. Yet, these can be copied & reproduced. We need something that is unique & cannot be duplicated to improve the safety level.
With the expertise of our team, we created ""Admiring"". A patent approved, batteryless, waterproof wearable device that helps us to protect the information on our smartphone by our choice.

Admiring is a finished product & what we need from you, our precious contributors, are your contribution & sharing of this campaign to your community to help us meet our manufacturer's MOQ on mass production.
What We Need & What You Get
We need to raise $20,000 USD to cover the initial batch production.
Our perks are simply at discount from our MSRP, so grab them while you can!
You will receive the product you ordered even if we don't reach our campaign goal.
Admiring is now available in 3 colours
White
Black
Red
Other Ways You Can Help If you can't contribute, that's alright. It doesn't mean you can't help.
Please use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.    Product Specification

column1: Violista Yoon Kyung Shin
violinista Jihee Lim
pianista Eun Sook Lee
In
questi ultimi anni la Scuola e, in genere, la società si sono molto
sensibilizzate e attivate nei confronti dell’educazione musicale e
coreutica, rivolta ai bambini e ai ragazzi.

Alla luce di questo, considerando l’importante valore delle esperienze vissute all’interno e all’esterno della scuola (saggi, visite d’istruzione, concorsi ecc.) nelle quali è possibile prendere una maggior conoscenza di sé e degli altri,si ritiene entusiasmante, per molte scuole, avere un’ulteriore opportunità per uscire dalla classe e vivere un’importante esperienza culturale, artistica e di scoperta di un nuovo territorio.

Omegna, Casale Corte Cerro e Ornavasso, con le loro strutture e le loro bellezze naturali, possiedono tutti i requisiti per ospitare un concorso rivolto alle scuole, nel quale riunire il percorso artistico, musicale e della danza, con la conoscenza di un territorio e delle sue caratteristiche, in un'unica esperienza straordinaria.

E’ da considerare straordinaria l'adesione all’edizione avvenuta in aprile 2015 di oltre tremila ottocento partecipanti provenienti da scuole provinciali e extraprovinciali, dalle regioni del Piemonte, Lombardia, Veneto, Emilia Romagna, Campania, Toscana, Liguria, Trentino Alto Adige, Valle D’Aosta, Sicilia e Calabria.

column4: >Nata nel 2003 tale manifestazione  ha saputo sin dalla prima edizione

column1: creare un ambiente sereno e attento, a misura di bambino,
raccogliendo negli anni esperienze di scoperta gratificando il
sacrificio, lo studio e nello stesso tempo la passione di migliaia di
ragazzi e docenti.
L’obiettivo
di questo evento è di creare un punto di riferimento solido e un
confronto sereno e costruttivo fra diverse realtà scolastiche, nel
quale condividere le varie esperienze didattiche e stimolare i
ragazzi, attraverso una forma trasversale di ascolto e confronto
artistico, a proseguire l’attività musicale e coreutica.
I tanti premi le borse di studio messe a disposizione aiuteranno molti studenti a continuare gli studi e le scuole a mantenere vive le attività indispensabili alla formazione culturale dei giovani.
Di cosa abbiamo bisogno e cosa otterrai!
Per l'organizzazione dei nostri concorsi quest'anno abbiamo pensato di rivolgerci al crowfunding per aiutarci a sostenere le spese, anche solo 1 € a noi sarebbe di aiuto!
Tutti i fondi versati verranno riversati nel sostenere le spese che l'Associazione Culturale
column2:
>""Arte""  affronta nell'organizzare questi eventi.

Aiutandoci otterrai la possibilità di assistere alle esecuzioni dei partecipanti e donando dai 50€ in su, otterrai la partecipazione gratuita a tutti i concorsi da noi organizzati

column1:
Cosa stiamo organizzando quindi?

L'Associazione Culturale ""Arte"" si impegna quest'anno, come nei passati ad organizzare i seguenti concorsi:
XII^ Edizione del concorso ""Insieme per Suonare Cantare e Danzare""
VII^ Edizione del concorso di composizione ""Gianni Rodari""
II^ Edizione del concorso ""Mando un Video""
Sul nostro sito potrai trovare tutti i dettagli su ogni concorso con il regolamento, comune a tutti e tre, tutti e 3 i concorsi vanno dall'11 al 17 di Aprile!
http://associazioneculturalearte.com/it/concorsi.php

I nostri concorsi sono rivolti a bambini e ragazzi che frequentano scuole dell’infanzia, primarie, secondarie di primo e secondo grado (statali e private), scuole di musica civiche e private, conservatori, scuole di danza, scuole per disabili del territorio nazionale.
Finalità
generali del progetto
<ul>
<li>
Diffondere il Linguaggio Musicale e Coreutico come
fattore educativo e di integrazione sociale nel sistema scolastico.
<li>
Promuovere il confronto costruttivo fra gli alunni e
gli insegnanti, premiando la loro dedizione alla conoscenza
dell'arte quale importante occasione di arricchimento personale.
<li>
Promuovere
le realtà scolastiche
che abbiano favorito l’inserimento, attraverso l’attività
artistica di soggetti diversamente abili.
Promuovere attraverso il concorso “Gianni Rodari”
le capacità intellettive e di conoscenza mediante un percorso di
composizione interdisciplinare. Per questa edizione è stata
inserita la nuova categoria “Gianni Ciak”, che prevede la
realizzazione di un cortometraggio su temi rodariani.
Premi
Verrà assegnato a tutti i concorrenti, solisti, formazioni e gruppi, che avranno riportato un
punteggio:
A. 100/100: diploma di 1° classificato e borsa di studio dal valore minimo di € 100,00
B. Da 98/100 a 99/100: diploma di 1° classificato e coppa.
C. Da 95/100 a 97/100: diploma di 1° classificato e medaglia.
D. Da 90/100 a 94/100: diploma di 2° classificato e medaglia.
E. Da 85/100 a 89/100: diploma di 3° classificato e medaglia.
F. Verranno inoltre assegnati i seguenti premi speciali:
1. borsa di studio dal valore di € 1.000,00 offerta dalla scuola di musica “Jeiem” alla scuola
pubblica o privata con il maggior numero di partecipanti e che abbia ottenuto una media di
valutazione pari o superiore al 98/100
2. borsa di studio del valore di € 200,00 per la categoria “canto solisti” (scuole private di
musica)
3. borsa di studio del valore di € 250,00 per la categoria “diversamente abili”
4. premio dal valore di € 300,00 offerto dal Comune di Omegna e premio “LA TORTA IN
CIELO” che prevede la partecipazione ai laboratori della Ludoteca Parco della Fantasia, per il
concorso “Gianni Rodari”
I premi verranno consegnati durante la premiazione nel giorno stesso dell’audizione.
Le borse di studio e i premi speciali verranno consegnati durante la cerimonia di premiazioni il 16 e
17 aprile 2016.

Relazione generale
Nata nel 2003 tale manifestazione  ha saputo sin dalla prima edizione
creare un ambiente sereno e attento, a misura di bambino,
raccogliendo negli anni esperienze di scoperta gratificando il
sacrificio, lo studio e nello stesso tempo la passione di migliaia di
ragazzi e docenti.
L’obiettivo
di questo evento è di creare un punto di riferimento solido e un

I tanti premi le borse di studio messe a disposizione aiuteranno molti studenti a continuare gli studi e le scuole a mantenere vive le attività indispensabili alla formazione culturale dei giovani.

Your little effort = big impact on children's education and future
What's the problem you are trying to solve?
Children from families with low financial
possibilities have limited access to books and pedagogical materials. This
project aims at making books accessible to children in order to develop their
communication skills, encouraging them to learn letters, reading and writing.
Why do I care about this project?
First, I consider education as a fundamental right
that children have. They don't have to suffer educationally because of their
parents' lack of financial means.
All children have the right to have access to a good
education, and to have a good start in life.
Second, coming from an area where the project will
take place, I know very well the situation and I am sure this project will have
a real impact.
How will the money be spent?
Children will receive some pedagogical materials: maps, dictionaries, maths, geography, biology books and atlases.
When will supporters see the difference?
We will launch  the 4th Edition of the project.
A small team of volunteers an I are involved in the implementation of the project: we buy the books and distribute them personally to pupils and school libraries.
Teachers on the ground make sure the materials
are read and used properly.
You will be kept informed on the project's
development.
","Your little effort = big impact on children's education and future
What's the problem you are trying to solve?
Children from families with low financial
possibilities have limited access to books and pedagogical materials. This
project aims at making books accessible to children in order to develop their
communication skills, encouraging them to learn letters, reading and writing.
Why do I care about this project?
First, I consider education as a fundamental right
that children have. They don't have to suffer educationally because of their
parents' lack of financial means.
All children have the right to have access to a good
education, and to have a good start in life.
Second, coming from an area where the project will
take place, I know very well the situation and I am sure this project will have
a real impact.
How will the money be spent?
Children will receive some pedagogical materials: maps, dictionaries, maths, geography, biology books and atlases.
When will supporters see the difference?
We will launch  the 4th Edition of the project.
A small team of volunteers an I are involved in the implementation of the project: we buy the books and distribute them personally to pupils and school libraries.
Teachers on the ground make sure the materials
are read and used properly.
You will be kept informed on the project's
development.",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

Short Summary
The Miracle Project
""Elaine Hall’s work
brings great hope."" -- Temple Grandin

The Miracle Project is a groundbreaking, fully inclusive, musical theater, film, and expressive arts program for students of all abilities -- and we need your help.

Using our innovative, proven methodology, students with and without disabilities express themselves through music, dance, acting, and story while working together to create and star in an original musical. 

The Miracle Project’s unique approach provides individuals with autism and other disabilities the tools to build communication, social skills, community and greater self-esteem. By focusing on strengths rather than deficits, the highly skilled staff and trained volunteers bring out the best in everyone.
1 in 68 children has been identified with autism spectrum
disorder (CDC).  Many of these children,
young adults and their families feel isolated and alone.  Often they are kicked out of traditional
music, dance, and theater programs due to their sensory challenges, or not
being able to keep up with their peers.
While their siblings go to dance class or baseball practice, they go to
therapy, which may only focus on their deficits rather than on their
abilities.
We believe every child and young adult with autism should have the opportunity to participate in the arts and create friendships with peers of all abilities.
The Miracle Project is where children, teens and young adults with autism find their voice .
OUR HISTORY
When acting and movement coach, Elaine Hall’s (Founder of
The Miracle Project) son was diagnosed with autism, at age two, traditional
therapies did not work for him.  She
discovered that she could reach him through music, movement and theater.  She then trained her creative friends,
musicians, dancers, actors how to understand autism from the inside out and
join her sons isolated world. Slowly her son emerged into our world. Elaine
developed these methods into the 'seven keys to unlock autism' and created The
Miracle Project, a theater and film program for all abilities and disabilities.
Since then, hundreds of children and young adults have
participated in The Miracle Project, developing meaningful friendships, easing
anxiety, while creating and performing in an original musical theater
production. Performers with disabilities find their voice and express
themselves with confidence.  Non-disabled
peers learn compassion and gain insights into those who experience the world
differently.  Audience members leave
these performances inspired and transformed by experiencing the ability of each
actor rather than their disability.
What We Need &
We need your help to create another season of miracles.
Each year we embark on a journey to reach more children and
young adults who have been deemed ‘unreachable’ and to foster friendships with
all abilities through music, dance, and theater.  We create an original musical based on the
thoughts, feelings and stories of our students.
We believe that our friends with disabilities
should rehearse and perform in positive and uplifting environment.  Our lean, spare non-profit uses its funding for rent and professional musicians  who <span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
original songs with our students.

column2: >With your help, we can create another Season of Miracles for more and more children with autism.

column1: Please join us on this journey so that we can continue to
create miracles for those who are desperately in need of community, friendship,
and the opportunity to express themselves through the arts.  Other than the joy of giving, what will you
get out of donating?
Here are some of our perks:
·
Tickets to our invitation only opening night
event where you will meet the students of The Miracle Project
·
A signed DVD of Autism: The Musical
·
A DVD of the new original musical with your name
in the credits as one of our donors.
·

Our love and appreciation! 

The Impact

The Miracle Project was the subject of a California University study funded by The National Endowment for the Arts.  Findings showed the fully inclusive teenage theater program to be evidence-based in easing anxiety, developing confidence and better communication skills.
The Miracle Project is committed to fully serving the
population that needs and wants its programs. We need your support at any level
to join us in bringing this program to the children, teens and young adults who
are still challenged  from the isolation,
depression and loneliness so common to families who have autism. While other
autism organizations raise funds for research that will help future
generations, The Miracle Project serves the children, teens and adults who need

support  RIGHT NOW.  

Risks &
We are honored to be considered innovators in the field of
using music, theater and the arts to create inclusive creative opportunities
for those with autism and other abilities. However, our challenge is in making
this program accessible to the many children, adults and families who are
requesting our program.  With government
funding for these types of arts programs declining, we need your support more
than ever.
We have a proven track record of overcoming obstacles:
·
10 years of classes and over 25 original
musicals created
·
Workshops and trainings across the US, Canada,
and in China, Israel, India and Africa.
·
A Board of Directors who include highly
respected business individuals and non for profit leaders in Los Angeles.
·
An Advisory Committee who include some of the
most respected names in the field of autism and disability such as Dr. Barry
Prizant, adjunct professor at Brown University
author, adult with autism, and professor at Adelphi University.
·
Creative leadership and training of all staff by
Elaine Hall, who has received honors from Autism Speaks, Autism Society of
America, and been a featured speaker and consultant to The United Nations.
·
Highly skilled staff managed by Ryan Berman, MSW
who specializes in positive supports for teens and young adults with

autism. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Beyond Money- we need your help spreading the word.
At the heart of The Miracle Project remains a mother, of a
now young adult with autism, who is driven to change the way the world
perceives disability.  Whether you donate
to our campaign or not, you can still be part of our miracle.
·
Share our video with others so that they can see
the ability within disability.
·
Let others know about The Miracle Project and
our students and show the video “Autism: The Musical.”
·
Volunteer in one of our programs.  Contact ryan@themiracleproject.org
·
Stay connected. Visit our website www.themiracleproject.org
or follow us  Facebook.
·
Share the message of inclusion and Be kind to
someone who needs your help.
